Dear Major McKay:

Before leaving for the East next Friday I wish to clear up outstanding problems pertaining to the Indian schools of this district in so far as my sphere of action is concerned. I am grateful for the information contained in your favor of the 18th instant and after careful consideration have come to the following decisions which I trust you will approve and the department as well.

(1) I have personally interviewed Miss Finan, have studied the excellent references she was able to produce and therefore confidently nominate her as the new teacher for the East Saanich Reserve School. (2) For the Songhees school I nominate Miss Francis for though not a certificated teacher she is certainly by far the best available now and if there is any delay in accepting her she will certainly take up other work already open to her talents. As the inspector has certified in his report on her work during the period when she was replacing Miss Blue, there can be no doubt that by her intelligence, enthusiasm, cheerfulness and discipline she gets excellent results all along the line. She is moreover young enough to endure a heavy curriculum as she enjoys perfect health. (3) In regard to the West Saanich School situation I quite appreciate the impossibility of two teachers teaching in the same little room so I have persuaded Father Lauzon to allow the department the use of his parish hall for a nominal sum of ten dollars a month until the new school has been built. Of course the department would have to provide the few desks required, improve the lighting somewhat, provide the fuel and possibly make a few minor alterations but I feel all this could be done for about $200.00 or less. Please let me know
if you approve of this arrangement. My address in the East will be 184 Bayswater Avenue, Ottawa, Ontario in case you may wish to contact me.

With every good wish I beg to remain

Sincerely yours in Christ,

[Signature]
Bishop of Victoria.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

I desire to refer to that portion of your letter of the 27th ultimo which mentioned the request you had received from Bishop Cody for a school at West Saanich.

I had an opportunity of discussing this matter with Bishop Cody on Saturday afternoon and he feels that there is a necessity for this school and that it should be operated under the general direction of the present teacher of the Tsartlip School. I understood from Bishop Cody that the proposed new room is a comparatively short distance from Tsartlip. It has been decided to recognize this second room as an adjunct of the Tsartlip School. Bishop Cody will nominate a qualified member of the Order to which the teacher at the Tsartlip School belongs. Salary will be allowed at the rate of $30 a teaching month, plus bonus.

During the course of our conversation Bishop Cody stated that he understood from Inspector Coleman that surplus desks were available at some other schools and consequently it would not be necessary to purchase new ones. If this is correct, you may arrange for the transfer of these surplus desks, but, if you have to purchase new desks, you may do so.
The Department also approves an expenditure of approximately $200 for minor alterations to the parish hall and we will allow a nominal rental of $10 a month for this building. I presume that arrangements will be made to open this extra room in September and no doubt you will advise me as soon as Bishop Cody nominates the teacher.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

During the first week of the month all the Day schools opened and the Kuper Is. Res. School. Attendance at two schools only could be considered good, Koksilah and Songhees, Tsartlip Sr. and Junior Rooms had a satisfactory enrollment from the opening date with a gradual improvement during the last week. St. Catherine's and Saanich Schools were quite low although a much larger attendance in both these is expected from now on as a lot of the Indians have returned from the Hop fields and fishing grounds during the last few days. Please note that the poor attendances were caused entirely on account of the Indian families being absent from their reserves at seasonal employment.

January 19th, 1946

Major D. M. MacKey, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

I wish to report that a serious situation has arisen in the Saanich I.D. schools with respect to the problem of transportation. As you know, the three sisters drive to and from the three schools each day in one car making a total round trip of about 26 miles.

In November last, the transmission failed in the Sister's Car, which is a 1941 Hudson, and the dealers and mechanics in Victoria have been trying ever since to get a replacement, but without success. In fact a telegram has been sent to the Hudson factory twice weekly ever since trying to get them to expedite shipment but so far no reply has been received, the factory simply ignore the telegrams. The result of all this has been the Sister's having to borrow the mechanics car, which convenience ended last week, and so now they are right up against it, no car and no immediate chance of getting repairs for their own car which has the broken transmission, unless of course there is some pressure put on the Hudson Factory to either send a reply to the many telegrams which they have ignored, or forward the necessary parts as ordered last November. The strike situation in the U.S. of course complicates matters still more.

The Teachers have transportation for Monday next only only, after that the schools will have to close until arrangements of some kind are made. In checking over the possibility of procuring some means for the Sister's to get to school and back daily, I find that the Sylvester U-Drive Co. in Victoria will provide a car at the rate of $30.00 per week, Sister's to supply gas, oil and repairs which they are willing to do providing the Department will pay the cost of the actual hire. As you know, Bus transportation is not available at hours suitable, and then it would mean a walk of 2 miles to and from the schools.

(over)
In giving this matter serious consideration and trying to arrive at some solution for the problem, I cannot see anything that would be at all suitable other than for us to hire a Car from the U-Drive Co., at the price stated.

It may be unusual for the Department to be asked to supply transportation for the teachers, but this is an unusual set-up and in my opinion at least calls for action in an unusual manner. I would therefore recommend that the Dept. pay the hire of this Car, and in the meantime try and put some pressure on the factory to ship the parts for the Sisters' car.

The schools will be closed on Tuesday next pending some suitable arrangements being made. The Sister's have done everything they possibly can do and only came to me as a last resort when they were unable to borrow a car any longer.

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.
January 21, 1946.

R. H. Moore, Esq., Indian Agent, Duncan, B.C.

I have your letter of January 19th regarding the difficulties being experienced by the Reverend teachers of the two Saanich Indian Day Schools in the matter of transportation to and from these schools.

As you know it is not the policy of the Department to provide transportation in such cases and I doubt if any exception will be made. The matter is, however, being referred to the department for a decision but I can give no assurance whatever that any assistance will be forthcoming. The teachers must find the means themselves to get to and from their work in the same way as any other employees of the Department.

It is noted that it may be necessary to close these schools for the time being as from Tuesday, January 22nd.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to forward herewith a copy of Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter to me of the 19th instant reporting that the teachers of the Saanich Indian Day Schools are experiencing difficulty in securing transportation to and from these schools, together with a copy of my reply to him of this date. It will be observed that the Agent recommends that transportation be provided for the teachers at the rate of $30.00 per week at the expense of the Department.

The responsibility of getting to and from work devolves on the teachers of our schools in the same way as any other employees and as I am not convinced the Department should accept this responsibility I regret that I am unable to endorse the Agent's recommendation.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Ottawa, 28th January, 1946.

Major D.M. MacKey, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 21st instant with reference to the difficulties experienced by the teachers of the Saanich Indian Day School in securing transportation. As you pointed out in the last paragraph of your letter, the responsibility of arranging transportation to and from the schools depends on the teachers in the same way as in the case of other employees. If we accepted responsibility in this particular case, we would probably have many more such applications.

The only possible solution that I can think of is that if they cannot get their car repaired it might be possible to rent for a few months some residence near the schools at which they can reside. We want to keep these schools open if at all possible and such arrangements might be made at fairly reasonable cost. The difficulty which they are experiencing in obtaining parts for their car should be overcome within the next few months.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

During the present emergency, there is no certainty that engines and tires would be available for the motor vehicle used in the transportation of the Cole Bay children to Tsartlip School, and in any case I am not prepared to recommend the establishment of any school bus service in Saanich at the present time, apart from the fact that I am not at all convinced that there would be accommodation at Tsartlip for these children.

A short time ago I recommended that Indian boys and girls attending Residential Schools on or near the coast might, under certain circumstances, be discharged on reaching their fourteenth birthday, in order that such children might engage in the fishing industry. Should the Department approve of my suggestion, it is quite possible that several boys and girls would, in the near future, be discharged from the Xuper Island Residential School. The vacancies caused by such discharges as I have referred to above, might well be filled by some, at least, of the Cole Bay children now in need of education.

For the reasons given above I am not prepared to recommend provision of day school facilities for the small number of children at present available on the Saanich Indian Reserve No. 3.

Yours very truly,

CHURCH UNITY OCTAVE

Structure and Tradition bear ample proof that the centre of unity is the Chair of Peter and he who seeks it elsewhere seeks in vain. It was upon St. Peter that Christ promised to build His Church as upon a rock against which the gates of Hell should not prevail. It was St. Peter whom Satan especially sought and for whom Christ especially prayed that his faith fail not and that being converted, she should convert his brethren. It was to St. Peter that Christ entrusted the office of shepherd¬ing His flock when He was about to leave the world for the right Hand of His Heavenly Father. It was to St. Peter, chosen first among the Apostles, that Christ said: "Feed my lambs, feed my sheep."

Yes, the Chair of Peter is the centre of unity, and he who seeks it elsewhere seeks in vain. Christ Himself established it there, and no man or set of men has a right to change it.

The past few centuries have witnessed many abortive attempts to undo what Christ has done, but every one has been doomed to failure. Self-opinionated men have arisen at different times and in different places to give utterance to Luther's "non serviam"—I will not serve. And separating themselves from the centre of unity, have lured countless others along with them. But when the branch separates from the vine it can bear no fruit. Christ said that and experience emphatically proves it. Rebellion against divinely constituted authority can end only in religious anarchy and religious chaos.

From Vatican Hill, the successor of St. Peter, whom Christ chose at the Chief Shepherd of Christendom, looks anxiously towards these sheep who have strayed from his fold. He recalls the prayer of Him whose Vice-regent here on earth he is: "That they all may be One, as Thou, Father, in Me and I in Thee; that they may be One in Us."

Setting aside the Octave from January 18 to January 25 as Church Unity Octave, Our Holy Father issues a special appeal to Catholics the world over to pray with him that God's grace may enlighten their minds and strengthen their wills to leave the path of error, to re¬trace their erring footsteps, to come back to their spirit¬ual Home, to the One Fold and the One Shepherd.

God grant that it may be so. Would that each one might be able to say as Cardinal Newman once said:

"Lead, Kindly Light, amid the encircling gloom,
Lead Thou me on!
The night is dark, and I am far from home—
Lead Thou me on!
So long, Thy power has blest me, sure it still
Will lead me on,
O'er moor and fen, o'er crag and torrent till
The night is gone;
And with the morn those angel faces smile
Which I have loved long since and lost a while."

--Cathedral Bulletin.
Dear Sir:

The members of the C.Y.O., Saanich Chapter have directed me to thank you sincerely for the interest you have shown in the concert they held in St. Ann's Academy, on Jan 10th.

We hope to make this event an annual one, with all the schools in the district taking part. We would like to have a drama festival for the Indians. If we succeed in this plan we will possibly call on the Department of Indian Affairs to put up a trophy to be awarded each year to the best group.

Meanwhile we have turned the greatest part of our share of the proceeds into an educational fund to promote contests among the school children, the first of which will be a spelling bee, to take place on the first Sunday in March.

Rev. Father Lauzon told us that you are from Victoria and that you know the situation in Saanich very well. It makes us hope to see our new school being built very soon.

Yours truly,

Ann Elliott

Dear Sir:

I presume that the estimates on the new schools are at present studied by your Department. So I present, for the last time, my case for a consolidated school in Saanich, B.C. I feel that a three-room-school is required to give accommodation to our rising school population. I am sending you a copy of the survey I made for Mr. R.F. Davey, the B.C. School Inspector.

My reason for asking for a consolidated school is the necessity of providing extensive vocational training to the Indian children. Some may look at St. Catherine as not being a complete success. Nevertheless the vocational training, among the girls especially, has brought about a marked improvement in the care they take of themselves, and for the few that are married, of their homes. Here in Saanich, it is easy to tell when a home is cared for by women who have had vocational training. In my opinion, it takes a daily routine of training to teach those children how to manage a home.

Although the academic progress of the pupils would be retarded somewhat on account of the time taken for vocational training, I feel that it would be for the benefit of the majority and that it would give them the type of education that would prepare them to better their home condition.

Discussing a future school with the Superior General of the Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, she told me that from the academic viewpoint, she that the efforts of the teachers are too scattered at present and that the same staff would do more and better work if they were in the same school. Moreover she told me that she does not favour the situation where one sister is isolated, although she would be ready to leave one sister in East Saanich if needed be.

The grouping of the children would help in many activities. I have had two older girls take a Girl-Guides course this summer. With the Sisters' supervision they would be able to start a Broyny pack.

The question of attendance is one that is not easily answered. But judging by the present situation, it should be very satisfactory. I have proposed and the Sisters have agreed to begin school at 9:30 to give the little ones more sleep in the morning.

Someone would have to be found to operate a bus. The Vancouver Island Coach Line have their nearest depot in Victoria and they charge for every mile out of the depot, which would mean, at least 30 miles of dead load. I have told Mr. Davey that I would be interested in the transportation contract.
Speaking with the Indians, I have found no objection to a consolidated school. Moreover, the larger the school, because they are always complaining (to quote one in the Daily Colonist) that the Department of Indian Affairs is only building 2x4 schools.

I have asked the Superior General of the Sisters of I.H.M. to write to you, giving her opinion on the new school and to tell you what she thinks would be required for the sisters' quarters. It would be well to provide for a social worker, as she told me that she would be willing to have one sister trained and sent here.

Personally, I hope that the efforts and the sacrifices the mission has made to provide facilities during the difficult years, will be rewarded by a liberal grant for a new school.

Remind me to Mr. Phelan and the others. Give my best regards to Major MacKay.

Dear Mr. Neary,

When Reverend Father Lauzon, S.M.M., suggested my writing to you in behalf of the Saanich Indian Schools, I experienced no difficulty in conceding to his suggestion. On the contrary, I consider it a pleasure to address one who has shown so many courtesies to the Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary in the past.

Since you are already acquainted with the work being done in the Saanich Indian Schools and the handicaps under which the Sisters labor, I feel that I need not say much. Briefly, therefore, may I express myself in favor of a consolidated school for the Saanich area with convent quarters for the Sisters and this for the following reasons:

1. It would offer facilities which cannot now be offered in a one-room school, such as, Home Economics and Manual Training.

2. A larger class would seem more practical than two smaller classes with the teacher concentrating on two or at the most three grades in the group.

3. With a larger group in the same grade level there would be greater possibilities for developing leadership and better school spirit which in turn would create an interest in education in their homes.

4. The living facilities for the Sisters on the same grounds would give more time for school work, and it would give them the opportunity to do catechetical work in neighboring areas where white children could profit by the instructions.

The above reasons are those submitted to Father Lauzon last year when the matter was being discussed. I submit them to you for consideration.

Thank you, Mr. Neary, for the many courtesies you have shown to the Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Sister M. Eucharis, Mother General

Dear Mr. Arneil:

Major General Pearkes, V.C., M.P., visited this office a day or two ago and brought up for consideration the following matters:

(1) That Indian high school students failing to pass their year be extended financial assistance to enable them to repeat the year when recommended by the principal of the school.

(2) That a consolidated school be built to replace the small day schools at East Saanich and Tsartlip.

I doubt if much objection could be taken to the suggestion in number 1. I should think, however, that it would be well to have the recommendation of Major Davey in addition to that of the principal concerned.

With respect to number 2, it will be recalled that Inspector Barry recommended a consolidated school similar to St. Catherines, Duncan, some years ago. Our early experience with St. Catherines, however, was such that the plan for a consolidated school for Saanich was dropped. As the subject has been revived, you might let me have any comments you wish to make following a discussion of the proposal with Major Davey. I should also like to have your views and those of Major Davey with respect to the suggestion contained in number 1.

Yours sincerely,

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

I have read your letter of September 28 to Mr. Arneil and would like to point out to you the following points which I feel should also be raised with Mr. Arneil:

(a) That the recommendation of the principal of the high school should also be supported by a recommendation from the Inspector of Schools for B.C.

(b) That the report card of the student concerned should be submitted to the Department for consideration when the case is being reviewed;

(c) That this exception be made only for pupils who have not been attending provincial schools.

I understand that General Pearkes raised this primarily with regard to Indian pupils who had been attending our own Indian schools and not to Indian pupils who had been attending provincial schools. His argument was that in their first year of high school, such pupils were at a handicap due to the difference in classroom procedures between a one-room Indian school and a large high school with many teachers and classrooms.

I also feel that in such cases of failure it should be made very clear that this will apply only to the first year of such failures, in other words that this failure exception clause would only apply to students in Grade 9.

Dear Sir:

This is to acknowledge yours of Nov. 3rd.

A day or so before I received your letter, Mr. W.S. Arneil, answering a letter that I had sent to Major Davey, told me that the Department was doing all it could to provide school accommodation to all the reserves. But that there are greater needs than ours. But as I pointed out before and as I am doing again in my answer, the need would be very great here also, if we had not offered the use of our church in East Saanich and our parish hall in West Saanich. The Department would have to provide for about 65 pupils with only a class-room large enough for 25 pupils.

I do not mind if the church is used as a school but I would like to see the hall free. It is the only hall that we have and both white and Indians are deprived of it, so that all our parish activities are at a standstill. I have started a C.Y.O among the young Indian people, but it very difficult to run it under the present condition. Yet now that many are coming our of school with a better of education, this society could help very much in keeping the teenagers together.

But as I told you so often, I want to have a consolidated school for the whole district.

Give my best regards to Major MacKay and Mr. Phelan.

Most sincerely yours,

Encl.
Duncan, B. C.
April 13th, 1943.

Indian Commissioner for B. C. P. O. Box. 70. Vancouver, B.C.

I would respectfully request authority to expend the approximate amount of $25.00 on burning and cleaning up dead brush, logs and rocks adjacent to the Saanich Indian Day School on Saanich I.R. No. 2, so that the cleared ground may be used as a playground for the school children.

The teacher there at present has made great progress with the work of getting the grounds cleaned up and vegetable and flower gardens planted, but as the burning logs and slash and general clearing of the brush is too heavy work for the children it will be necessary for us to engage a couple of men for about 5 or 6 days. I would like to have this authority as soon as possible and might say that food supplies can be issued in payment of same.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
April 19, 1943.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6424, file 870-5, part 1)
As soon as your above noted letter was received at this Office the necessary authority was given to Miss Wadel to get the playground equipment etc., as soon as conveniently possible. However, the difficulty of finding a cleared space to put the swings etc., and use for a playground was encountered. There was a field adjoining the school that had grown up with small brush and blackberry vines which would be quite suitable if cleared. Miss Wadel suggested that she and the pupils clear this field, doing a little each day after school, to which I readily agreed. She has now completed this work and I would like to recommend that we pay Miss Wadel and the pupils $10.00 for doing this work, actually there was about $30 worth done, out of land clearing money. I told Miss Wadel that I was going to recommend this and she said that if they got the money it would be used for all the children at a Christmas party at the school. I have great pleasure in recommending this expenditure and feel that something well worth while has been accomplished at a fraction of the cost we would have to pay had we to hire the work done.

A Voucher for that amount, accompanied by paylists in duplicate is attached hereto.

I enclose herewith a letter dated the 2nd instant received from Mr. Indian Agent Moore forwarding the enclosed voucher for $10.00 covering the clearing of land adjacent to the Saanich Indian Day School to permit the erection of playground equipment.

It will be noted that the pay list is incomplete, but as this would involve the payment of Miss Wadel for the time that she was already employed as a teacher, it would appear to me that it may not be possible to approve of the voucher under treasury regulations and, if such is the case, I would suggest that under the circumstances the Department might be able to approve of a $10.00 grant to the school for Christmas prizes.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for V.C.

AIR MAIL

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 11th instant, with reference to the work done at the Saanich Indian Day School by the teacher and pupils.

In view of the recommendation contained in the second paragraph of your letter, the Department approves an expenditure of $10.00 for Christmas prizes for the pupils at this school. It should be understood, however, that this is not to form a precedent, as it has not been the practice of the Department to supply funds for Christmas prizes for the past two or three years.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I would like to make application for authority covering an expenditure of approximately Four Dollars ($4.00) per month—$3.50 being for hot drink supplies and 50¢ for coal oil, for the Saanich Indian Day School, effective from January, 1945 to the end of the present academic year.

I would advise that the building used for school purposes is heated by furnace, but the Missionary has kindly loaned the Teacher a Coal Oil Stove for use in making the hot drink, and it is estimated that 50¢ per month will cover the coal oil required.

It will also be necessary to purchase 18 enamel cups and an open pot or kettle, the cups come at 30¢ each—and the kettle $1.50.

The teacher feels that the pupils are badly in need of this added nourishment, and I would like to strongly recommend that the same be authorized.

(R.H. Moore)

Dear Mr. Phelan:

There is a discrepancy about the rentals for the "Saanich Indian Day School" and the "Tsartlip Junior Indian Day School" which needs to be cleared up before the new school year. Briefly the situation is this: from the opening of the "Saanich Indian Day School" (on the East Reserve called L.R. #2) till last summer it was agreed between the department and myself that I should receive the sum of $10.00 per month token rental for the new school I had erected. Last summer in my personal interview with you I represented that this sum was rather small and you agreed it should be raised to $20.00 per month the new rate to be effective beginning last September. In regard to the "Tsartlip Junior Indian Day School" opened on the West Reserve last Fall, we agreed that the monthly rental would be $10.00 per month payable not to me but to the parish priest Rev. K. Lauzon C.M.M. Through Father Lauzon I now discover that with the exception of one payment covering a few months he has not been receiving any rental at all.

I think the confusion must be due to the department being under the impression you had left the rental of the East Reserve at $10.00 whereas it was raised to $20.00 last summer. I should like to have the matter ironed out to our mutual satisfaction before the Fall term if possible.

Yours in Christ,

[Signature]

Major R.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

You will please remember that when the Day school at the Saanich I.R. #2 was opened about three years ago that it was necessary for us to construct two toilets, one for the boys and one for the girls. At that time it was proposed that we also erect one for the Teacher but somehow or other it got overlooked and has not been built since.

I have now received a request from the present Teacher, Rev. Sister Maria Socorra, that a new toilet be erected for her own use and which cannot be used by the Indians.

This is a reasonable request and one that I have no hesitancy in recommending for your early consideration and approval. Taking the price of the other toilets as a basis of cost of this new one, I estimate that it will entail the expenditure of approximately $15.00. Mitchell & Anderson Lumber Co. in Sidney will be able to build it and then haul it to the reserve and set it up.

Windy advise in this regard as soon as conveniently possible.

Ottawa, October 6, 1949

Major D. M. MacKay,
Director of Indian Affairs,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Major MacKay,

Further to our conversation regarding a new school to take care of the Indian population on Saanich, I have received another communication from Father Lauzon who, as you know, is keenly interested in having a consolidated school for the Indian children on the various Reservations in Saanich. Father Lauzon tells me that he has been in touch with Mr. Arneill regarding this matter.

Father Lauzon also advises me that there are more than 70 children of school age, and he believes that their educational needs can best be supplied through a consolidated school. The small parish hall which has been used as a classroom appears to be needed for its original purposes. It is hoped that a suitable building can be erected and that emphasis may be placed on vocational training which is particularly needed amongst the Indians.

I do not know whether you have heard from Mr. Arneill. You will no doubt recall that you promised to write him to the effect that interest in a consolidated school for Saanich is being revived. May I assure you that your interest in this matter is greatly appreciated, and I hope that it will be possible to include an item in the estimates to cover the construction of a school in the near future.

Yours sincerely,

George R. Pearkes
October 17, 1949.

Major General G.R. Pearkes, V.C., M.P.,
House of Commons,
OTTAWA,
Ontario.

Dear General Pearkes:

I wish to refer to your letter of October 6th, regarding the representations made by Reverend Father Lauson, O.M.I., that a consolidated Indian school be built to replace the Indian day schools now in operation at East Saanich and Tsartlip.

Immediately following our discussion of this subject, during your visit to this office, I wrote to Mr. Arneil but have not yet received a reply. This is quite understandable as he would, no doubt, wish to have the Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia make a survey to determine whether such a school should be provided. As soon as I receive a reply from Mr. Arneil, I will be glad to write to you further on the subject.

Yours sincerely,

Director.

DMM/BM
October 25, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

With reference to the Director's letter of September 28th, 1949, in connection with suggestions made by Major General Pearkes, V.C., M.P., regarding educational matters, I am enclosing a memorandum dated October 8th, from District School Inspector Davey, dealing with the two points specifically mentioned by Major General Pearkes.

My own views in connection with these matters are in line with those of Mr. Davey and it is felt that his memorandum covers the matter fully.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
October 8, 1949.

MEMORANDUM TO INDIAN COMMISSIONER:

I refer to the Director's letter dated September 28th, 1949, in which reference is made to matters brought up for consideration by Major General Pearkes, V.C., M.P.

(1) "That Indian high school students failing to pass their year be extended financial assistance to enable them to repeat the year when recommended by the Principal of the school."

Although it has been the general practice of the Department to refuse assistance to enable students to repeat a year's high school work, there have already been departures from this general policy. I do feel, however, that the Department might be somewhat more lenient in its rulings where both the Principal and myself recommend assistance.

(2) "That a consolidated school be built to replace the small day schools at East Saanich and Tsartlip."

The problem of the most suitable type of school to serve the four reserves at the north end of the Saanich peninsula has concerned me for some time. In the early part of this year I made a visit to the four reserves, namely, Tseycum, Pauquachin, Tsartlip and Tsawout and I attach herewith a rough sketch map showing the location of the reserves and the distances involved. There would be no difficulty in having a bus operate so as to serve these reserves and had it not been for the experience at St. Catherine's and several other points where we have Indian children attending Provincial schools by bus, I would undoubtedly have recommended the establishment of a consolidated school. I find, however, that wherever the teacher is removed from contact with the home, there is a falling off in the regularity of attendance; in fact, this problem becomes so acute that the benefits of consolidation are lost. One factor appears to be of paramount importance in the successful operation of our Indian schools, that is continued contact between the teacher and the home.
You will remember that we have two schools established in this area, one on the Tsartlip Reserve and another on the Tsawout Reserve (East Saanich). The operation of both these schools has been reasonably successful. On the two remaining reserves, Pauquachin (Cole Bay) and Tseycum, the school population is not sufficient to justify the establishment of separate schools and consequently, a taxi is now being hired to transport the pupils from these two reserves to the Tsartlip School. How successful this will be remains to be seen but in view of the very small number of school age children, there appears to be no alternative.

I would recommend that the new school on the Tsartlip Reserve be of two rooms, preferably of such plan that the construction of an addition at a later date would present no difficulty. This would serve the three reserves on the west side of the peninsula.

I am convinced that we should maintain our school on the East Saanich Reserve for the present time. The distance which a bus would have to travel from the East Saanich Reserve in a circuitous route to serve the Union Bay and Cole Bay reserves, would be 9.5 miles as measured by car speedometer. This means that the bus would have to leave the East Saanich Reserve at about 8:15 in order to arrive at the Tsartlip School at the usual opening time. Although this would present no difficulty in a white community, our experience indicates that the necessity of pupils catching a bus at 8:15 would result in a high rate of absenteeism.

In June of 1948 a tabulation was made of the school population on the four points concerned. This indicated a school age population of 152 on the three reserves on the west side of the peninsula, however, the school enrolment and attendance indicates that there are a large number of children who are apparently not available for attendance at a Day school. In fact, in the 1947-48 year the enrolment never exceeded 39.

The school should be located on the Tsartlip Reserve, so as to serve the two other reserves on the West side of the peninsula. A site adjacent to the existing one-room Department-owned school would be the most suitable location.

The school should be provided with a teachersage, for although this area is thickly populated for a rural community, the teachers
would undoubtedly have difficulty in finding boarding places within reasonable distance of the school.

R.F. Davey,
Inspector of Indian Schools.

Mr. MacKinnon should teach at Anaham Lake after the school closes at Ulkatcho since the Anaham Lake Indians are better off and do not leave home during the summer months. A separate report has gone in on this project.

Purpose of Survey:

This survey has been prepared with respect to the educational needs of the Indian children living at or near Anahim Lake, in the Bella Coola Agency.

A suggestion has been made by Mr. Indian Agent Christie, of Bella Coola, that a seasonal school be established at Anahim Lake, and he has been asked for further particulars.

As Mr. Christie may have some difficulty in obtaining the required information, owing to the difficulty of a journey into Anahim Lake from Bella Coola, the following information, which is only of an approximate nature, has been outlined in the hope that it may be of some assistance to you and the Department.

Procedure Adopted:

Mrs. Lehman R.M., who before her marriage was Miss Jane Bryant, our Field Matron in this area called on me in Vancouver, January 14, 1941, and was most helpful.

Mrs. Lehman was not certain of the names of some of the children or of their ages, though the information is no doubt fairly correct. This information has been put together in the form of a survey report, but it should be understood that I have not visited the area myself and have no personal knowledge of the people.

Indian Children Available for School:

The number of Indian children available for school would be 16, and only one child on the average would become available each year to take the place of the two reaching maximum school age on the average.

Attendance could no doubt be very good for some years and an average of at least 10 might be expected.
Location of Proposed School:

There are two houses which might be rented for a school. One is a log cabin about 16 feet by 24 feet. This is owned by Stanley Dowling, a white man, who is Postmaster at Anahim Lake.

The above house is only about one year old and it has been used as a store. I understand that the owner might rent it for the sum of $5.00 per month. There are three windows on one side and one on the other. This house will be referred to as the Dowling house.

The second possible house for a school is a store house belonging to the Hudson's Bay Co. at Anahim Lake. This H.B.C. store house is used by Paul Kresenmuk, though he does not make any great use of it. It is an old building and will be referred to as the H.B.C. house.

If it is decided to operate either a regular or seasonal Indian school at Anahim Lake, consideration should be given to the renting of the Dowling House, as it is obvious that it would be the best available building for a school house.

The location is quite close to Chief Squinas's house at Anahim Lake.

Accommodation for Teacher:

There would be no difficulty with regard to finding accommodation for the teacher, who could no doubt board and room at Mrs Bowser's within half a mile of the Dowling house mentioned above.

Period of Instruction at Proposed School:

I understand that many of the Indians, including some parents of children mentioned above, live at or near Anahim Lake during the months of November, December, January, and February. From March to June some of the Indians are away from their winter homes engaged in trapping mainly muskrats.

Though some of the parents are away for these spring months the people are so anxious for education that the children would remain at Anahim Lake with older members of the same family or with friends and attend school in March, April, May, and perhaps June.

The better time for a seasonal school would no doubt be for the five months November 1st to March 31st, but it could be given a trial from March 1st 1941 to June 30th 1941 if the Department had any available funds as the Indians seeing the success of the Ulkatcho Seasonal Indian Day School appear anxious to have education this year.

A full eight or nine month school would not be probably a success, I am informed, for the Indians would become restless.

Dear Sir:

Your file 15/2/9699
Re Proposed School Anaham Lake

Your letter of the 21st instant is acknowledged enclosing copy of Captain Barry's educational survey for Anaham Lake District.

The Report is I consider complete and accurate with the exception of certain ages and names of some of the children which do not agree with that in my census book, but there is no substantial error which might decide either for or against this project.

Location of Proposed School

It is agreed that the Dowling house is the best available building and slightly more central.

Period of Instruction

It will in my opinion be difficult to get two teachers for part time schools at Anaham Lake and Ulkatcho which leaves very little choice as to the months these schools shall be operated. There is no question that from November 1 to the end of February is the best time for the Ulkatcho School, and from then on to the end of June at Anaham Lake. Another point is that the Ulkatcho children stay in the village while school is on but some of the Anaham Lake children including Whites may have in some cases to come four or five miles on horseback and the days are getting longer and warmer from March on. Another consideration is that it is to the advantage of the Department to have a school teacher like Mr. MacKinnon at Ulkatcho during the winter months to more or less look after things and especially the children.
Probable Cost

The estimated cost of $500.00 for operation of this school for four months including lumber for construction of desks, blackboard, labour, and freight should be approximately correct. The box heater will not be necessary this year at least as Stanley Dowling agreed to rent the building for $5.00 including use of a heater.

Recommendation

A gratifying report on the Ulkatcho School was received from Mr. MacKinnon in which it is noted that five pupils did not miss a day which is a record for any day School in this Agency and the attendance averaged 12.36 out of a possible 18. Some of the pupils started late but apparently attended very regularly thereafter. At Anaham Lake I expect the attendance to be equally satisfactory and it is remarkable that these Indians have expressed so keen a desire for education. Last fall Torway Squinas asked me to send him some school books with which to teach his children but I do not know how much success he had as his education is very limited and he has more or less been self-taught.

In view of these circumstances and the fact that this Band has cost the Department nothing for Education up to 1939-40, I strongly recommend that a Seasonal School is started for the Ulkatcho Indians at Anaham Lake from March 1 to June 30 and that the Department recommend the appointment of Mr. C. F. MacKinnon as teacher on the termination of his duties at the Ulkatcho School.

Your obedient servant,

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
Vancouver, B. C.

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are sixty (60) Roman Catholic Indian children of school age on the Anaham Reserve, Williams Lake Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, for whom at present no educational facilities are provided;

THAT funds are available in Vote 166, 1942-43, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for the establishment of a day school on the Anaham Reserve.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

PRECIS FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL

Establishment of the Anaham Roman Catholic Indian Day School, Anaham Reserve, Williams Lake Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia.
Ottawa,
December 30, 1942.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Establishment of a day school
on the Anaham Reserve, Williams
Lake Indian Agency, Province of
British Columbia.

In a letter dated December 7, 1942, Indian Commissioner MacKay states that he recently visited the Anaham Reserve and found that there are 60 children of school age for whom no educational facilities are available. The Anaham Band is the largest one in the Williams Lake Agency. The reserve on which their village is built contains some of the finest cultivated land in the Chilcotin District. The village is situated on the main highway 70 miles west of Williams Lake and is supplied with a domestic water system.

All the Indians of this band are members of the Catholic Church. There is a community hall belonging to the Church which can be used for school purposes, although it may be necessary to expend about $200.00 for material to make it more comfortable. The Indians have agreed to contribute the labour free of charge.

In view of the information outlined above, I believe it would be advisable to open a school on this reserve and, in order to comply with Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, an Order-in-Council is required. I attach Memorandum to Council.

Acting Director.

PP

January 2, 1943.

EDUCATION:

The Caribou Indian Residential School opened on September 1st and the Anaham Indian Day School on September 4th, 1945. The return of the pupils to the Residential School was much better this year. It was expected that there would have been very poor attendance at the Anaham Indian Day School during September due to the fact that most of the Indians were still having away from the main Reserve, but a special effort was made to get their children back in time and practically all the pupils who attended last year are now back.

There are now fourteen pupils in the senior room and they show a very keen competitive spirit. Sr. Mary of the Angels, teacher of the senior room, visited St. Mary's school at Mission last year and saw the Pro-rec work, and now has her pupils started on this type of physical education.

During the Indian Commissioner's visit, a site was chosen for a new school on this Reserve, and, as soon as it is possible to get a representative meeting, the Indians will be asked to surrender this land to the Department for school purposes.

The Roman Catholic Church has not yet found a teacher for the Alexis Creek Day School, but Fr. Hennessy will, in all probability, fill for the winter months, i.e., November to March. With the erection of a school and living quarters, it may be possible to get the Missionary Sisters of Christ the King to supply a teacher for this school next year.

It was thought that there might be great difficulty in getting new pupils for the Cariboo Indian Residential School this season due to the non-payment of Family Allowance to pupils attending Residential Schools, and, although the principal advises me that he is ten pupils short of the number provided for by the Department in the grant, there

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING MARCH 31st, 1945, ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY

EDUCATION

Anaham Indian Day School: The attendance at this school has been quite good for a start, and it is expected that when the family allowance comes into operation it will be an added inducement to Indian parents to make arrangements for most of their children to attend regularly. Already some of the Indians who live on the meadows are making arrangements to build houses on the Anaham Indian Reserve No. 1 to enable the children to attend school. The Missionary Sisters to Christ the King, who are teaching this school, are very competent and are doing good work. Clothes have been made up by the children under the supervision of the Sister Superior out of used Army clothing.

The relationship between the children and the Sisters is very good and every night the Sisters' home is full of children. With the erection of a suitable school building, which should include a fairly large club room, much good work will be accomplished by the Sisters on the Reserve outside of School hours. Building material is becoming more plentiful and I would suggest that immediate attention is given to planning a suitable, modern school building for this reserve, including accommodation for the Sisters and a dispensary.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
Dr. Pomp is leaving Williams Lake on July 15th, 1945 and sent his resignation to the Department. Dr. L. E. Avery, Orillia, Ontario, older brother of Dr. Avery now assisting Dr. Baker at Quesnel, will arrive at Williams Lake on or before that date and a recommendation has gone forward that he receive the Indian grant.

It is quite clear, however, that a full time doctor is required in this agency for Indian work. All that is being done at present is of an emergency nature, where a patient has to be brought to hospital. A portable X-ray should also be provided and also equipment for testing eyes so that clinics can be held at the reserves, when all the Indians are home, such as during the periodic visits of the Priest.

Sister Mary St Paul, R.N., Anaham Reserve, is doing very good work without any co-operation from the visiting doctor, and I would suggest that when a new school building is erected on this reserve, that a small hospital is provided as a preventorium for T.B. children of this agency with a few beds for emergency cases. The small hospital at Alexis Creek and the services of a nurse there could then be dispensed with, since, even with a resident doctor at Alexis Creek, there is no X-ray or other equipment to do anything but a minor operation.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
AGENT'S REPORT FOR JUNE QUARTER, 1945 - WILLIAMS LAKE.

The Anaham Indian Day school was inspected by Mr. T. S. Carter, Provincial School Inspector, and the Department will have received a copy of his report which I think is quite good for the past year. Most of the criticism the inspector had to offer was regarding the building and equipment, but I think the Department will realize that a very good beginning has been made and that the attendance, which will undoubtedly increase with the application of the Family Allowance, was very good and consistent throughout the year and justifies the erection of a modern building as soon as conditions permit. I am of the opinion that the Inspector has been rather conservative in his grading of the teachers, especially in regards personality and health.

Wm. Christie.
Indian Agent.

General;

A rather interesting incident occurred in connection with the Anaham Day School. Upon the teacher asking how many had a bath during the week-end, one boy who had answered in the negative, asked to get out about 11 a.m. He did not return to school until 2:00 p.m. and upon the teacher asking the reason, he informed her that he had gone for a bath and clean clothes.

REPORT ON WILLIAM'S LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF OCTOBER, 1944

Education:

The Anaham Indian Day School opened on October 2nd with an attendance of about 40 pupils although some had not yet returned from their meadows. The School was visited by Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, during his visit to the Agency and also by Mr. MacArthur, Provincial School Inspector for the district, who happened to be in the vicinity and who was favourably impressed with the teachers. Major MacKay also visited the Redstone Day school which opened on November 1st and Father Hennessey arrived before we left to get everything ready for the opening. The Cariboo Indian Residential School was also visited accompanied by the Indian Commissioner.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
There are forty-seven pupils attending Anaham Indian Day School, an increase of six over last year. There are still sixteen children of school age from this Reserve who are not attending school, and the parents of these children have had their Family Allowances cut off on this account. One hesitates to take any further action on account of the fact that most of the Indians are back on their meadows feeding cattle or trapping. On the whole, I think the attendance is very good, one child having a perfect attendance for the quarter with an average attendance for those on the register of approximately 85 per cent.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
AGENTS REPORT FOR QUARTER ENDING JUNE 30, 1946.

EDUCATION:

The Anaham Indian Day School had a fairly successful year with approximately 75% attendance of those on the register during this quarter. The whole Reserve moved out to Riske Creek for the week ending June 22nd, to take in the stampede, taking the children with them and I am afraid there is nothing much can be done about this since it is about the only entertainment that really appeals to the Indians in this Agency.

The Sisters teaching school here are, I consider, doing excellent work and it is hoped that better facilities will be provided in the near future with the erection of a new school building.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.

I refer to Mr. Phelan's letter of October 7th regarding an adjustment in the school calendar for the above mentioned school.

This school did not open until October 4th because there were no pupils on the reserve to attend. Attendance during the month of September is usually very poor due to the fact that the majority of the families are absent from the village cutting hay. This condition was accentuated this year due to the very wet weather. Inspector Davey is of the opinion that it is usually poor practice to change the normal school calendar for any particular school, but the conditions on this particular reserve are so unusual and attendance during the month of September is so poor that he believes an experiment at this point would be justified.

The Indians on this reserve must of necessity be away from the reserve during the greater part of September in order to harvest the hay crop on their meadows which are located at a considerable distance from the reserve and it is impossible for the children to attend the Anaham school when the families are away at the meadows. Unfortunately we have no record of the previous attendance at the Anaham school during the month of September for previous years but Inspector Davey believes that an inspection of these would indicate that attendance is extremely poor during this month.

Dear Mr. Christie:

Your letter of December 18, reached us Tuesday the 4th. We are somewhat surprised that the Department does not deem it advisable to forego our teaching in the month of September, since, as you say, we would not have had any pupils at all this year during that month, on account of the flooded condition of the meadows and the necessity for the parents to be away from the Reserve later than usual. In fact, all the years that we have been teaching in Anaham, that is since 1944, the attendance at school in September has been very low. If we look at the Register for those past four years, we do not count any more than about 10 pupils altogether in the two classes, from the opening of the school to September 15. On the other hand, the work does not call them away from school before July 15, therefore it might be just as well to begin school in the middle of September and have a good attendance all the year. Otherwise, it does not profit the children, and everybody knows what a headache it is for the teacher to start everything over again for the late pupils.

Dear Bernard:

I was very much perturbed regarding the attached inspection reports covering District School Inspector Davey's visit to the above-mentioned School on September 27th and after studying them I visited His Excellency, Archbishop Duke, and discussed them with him at some length.

As you are aware, there is temporarily at present a great scarcity of Catholic teachers in our Day Schools in this Province, and the same condition exists, although to a lesser degree, in those schools where Sisters of various Orders are teaching. The Sisters teaching in British Columbia are all fully qualified and from teaching Orders, with the exception of the above School, which Order is primarily a missionary congregation, doing extensive missionary work in the Orient and who only accepted work in the Anaham district because of continued request and then only because of their inability to carry out additional missionary duties in the Orient, due to war conditions.

Last year, at the Anaham School, Sister Mary St. Bernard was in charge and was most successful in making a real contribution, not only in the classroom but with the children's parents and throughout the entire community. She was transferred to senior duties in the East and was replaced by Sister Mary Immaculata. I am writing to the Mother General of the
Missionary Sisters of Christ the King, drawing to her attention the desirability and necessity of qualified teachers occupying teaching positions at the Ansham School and it is my hope that this important matter may be rectified at a fairly early date.

Yours sincerely,

W.S. Ameil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mother General:

I would like to draw to your attention a difficulty which we are experiencing in our Anaham Indian Day School, Hanceville, B.C.

You will recall that last year Sister Mary St. Bernard had charge of the Anaham School and during that period she made an excellent contribution, not only in the classrooms with the children, but with the parents and adult population throughout the entire community. Her transfer to greater duties, while fully appreciated, was very keenly felt by all concerned in the community and in this Branch, where her marked ability was so greatly shown in the improvement in school enrolment and regularity in attendance. As already mentioned, however, her transfer to more important work in your congregation is fully appreciated.

A replacement by Sister Mary Immaculate is also appreciated and insofar as her devotion to her work and her conscientious approach is concerned, it leaves nothing to be desired. Our difficulty arises, however, in the minimum qualifications necessary for any person to assume a teaching position and particularly so amongst the children of a native group such as we are catering to at Anaham, where their family background is lacking from a language point of view as well as lacking background where general information is available in the home. We are very much afraid as time goes on without the best possible academic results being obtained at School that our serious attempt to provide an adequate Day School to improve and to educate the young folks amongst our native population there will be retarded.

In writing to you regarding this matter, I am not unmindful that the congregation of Christ the King are not a teaching Order but a missionary congregation, doing splendid work here.
as well as in the far East and we were fortunate that the congregation established themselves at Anaham, with resultant benefit to our native people, nor am I unmindful that possibly the great progress made last year by Sister St. Bernard encouraged us too hopefully and to appoint where we felt that in a reasonable time our native population would be raised by education in school to a par with the natives of more progressive areas.

In considering the above matter it would be greatly appreciated if assistance could be rendered us to the extent that if within your congregation you have one or two Sisters experienced to some degree in teaching where English is spoken, you could find it convenient to possibly make them available at Anaham.

In closing may I take this opportunity to sincerely thank you for the work which the Sisters of Christ the King are doing for us here.

With kindest regards,

Yours sincerely,

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Quotations will be forwarded as soon as available.
Two weeks ago I took the Mother General of the Missionary Sisters of Christ the King to the Alexis Creek Indian Reserve at Redstone Meadows and also to Anaham Reserve, and I believe they are anxious to get established on the Anaham Reserve to begin with; with four Sisters of the Order, two as teachers, one a trained nurse and the other a cook and gardener.

Their idea is not only to provide teachers for the Day Schools and a nurse to look after the sick and do social work but to establish a training centre for Indian girls to learn nursing and for teachers on the Reserves.

The fact that the Mother General in the course of her conversation thought that it would be a good idea if one of their order took a dental course shows that they are, above everything, practical and I think they should be given every encouragement. I also understand that they have been running Sanatoriums and there is certainly a very urgent need for a Preventorium in this Agency. It is very discouraging to see so many children suffering from T.B. which has got too great a start to give any hope of their recovery even if there is accommodation for them at Coqualeetza. As you also know there is practically nothing being done on the Reserves in this Agency in the way of public health work. The present medical situation gives no hope of having clinics on the Reserves, and there is, therefore, no possibility of checking any disease until it is well established and requires hospitalization.

No doubt Archbishop Duke has already discussed the set-up with you since it would appear that it is now just a question of accommodation. The Indians have already put up a log cabin for the Priest at Anaham, and the Priest's house, which is 21' x 14' can be used by the Sisters. This is quite a good building divided into two bedrooms and a kitchen-livingroom. I would suggest that a lean-to for a kitchen and bedroom is built 30' x 12'. I would imagine
the Department would be prepared to put up a modern building similar to the schools that were built at Bella Bella and Kitimat but this will no doubt have to wait until after the War. Meanwhile, there will be no waste entailed in alterations to present buildings since these can always be used by the Indians or the Department for some other purpose.

There may be some difficulty in getting Indians to work on the school buildings at present since all are busy harvesting and will be now for some time but authorization for the purchase of the attached list of supplies and material is requested if the Anaham Day School is to be opened this year.

It should be further pointed out that the cost of alterations to the building to be used as a Day School has been small and that the Indians have done all labour so far gratuitously.

It should also be noted that the main building of the teacherage has been contributed by the Indians, since it was built for the Priest and therefore the cost of the addition is far below the cost of an entirely new building suitable for this purpose.

It is regretted that provision was not made in the Estimates for this expenditure but it was not possible for me to foresee that such a program as outlined by the Sisters and the Archbishop Duke would be put into effect until after the War.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Anaham Indian Day School

Indications are that 70 children will be available to attend this school and in view of this it would appear desirable to have two classrooms which of course would necessitate the appointment of two teachers. Mr. Christie has been requested to advise if suitable accommodation is available for a second classroom.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

Enclosed herewith is a requisition for 4 rolls of poultry fencing wire to enclose the Anaham Indian Day School and teacherage.

I might say that the Anaham Indians have removed the stones and plowed out the ground around these buildings which will be planted with trees and garden by the Sisters who are teaching school there. These school buildings should be fenced to protect the windows from horses and cattle which frequently are running loose around the reserve.

Also, a garden with flowers and trees would do much to improve the appearance of the place and also will probably be an incentive to the Indians to do something about beautifying their own homesites.

It will require approximately 612 feet of fencing, so that 4 rolls will be necessary. It is difficult to get this wire around town, and Mr. Gosman is the only one who had 4 rolls available, and he has promised to hold same until I hear from you.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver, B. C.

Enclosed herewith is a list of children of school and pre-school age belonging to the Anaham Band, and also a surrender of land for school purposes on Anaham Indian Reserve, No. 1.

The Anaham Indian Day School is now in its second year of existence in the makeshift building formerly used as a Community Hall by the Indians. I think the results so far achieved have been very good and that the time has come to erect a modern school building on this Reserve in conjunction with a ward for emergency hospital patients and perhaps a small preventorium for T.B. cases.

Considerable thought has been given to the desired set-up on Anaham Reserve, the largest reserve in this Agency, with approximately 4,000 acres cultivable when irrigation is extended, in the centre of the Chilcotin, and adjacent to the Alexis Creek, Stone, Nemaiah Valley and Toosey Reserves, with the object of making the most advantage of the services of the Missionary Sisters of Christ the King, who specialize in teaching and nursing amongst native races. In this regard, I would direct your attention to Inspector T.G. Carter's reports of June 14th, 1945.

Regarding Sr. Mary St. Paul, R.N., her reports speak for themselves, and more so from the reduction in hospitalization at the Chilcotin General Hospital at Alexis Creek. There are other advantages which cannot be estimated yet, such as the interest taken in gardening, in the children after school hours, and so on.

The attendance so far, I think, is satisfactory,
taking into consideration the fact that most of them sending only one or two legs of a sacrifice. They live anywhere from five to fifteen miles where they feed cattle during the winter to their trapping activities. Then conditions in many cases are poor on the reserve because there is a lack of accommodation.

There are forty-seven children attending the Anaham Day School, one of these being a boy attending to Nazko Reserve. The average attendance for the last quarter was forty. Twenty-one children belong to the Anaham Indian Reserve are not attending any school because, for the most part, their parents are out trapping and feeding cattle. With better houses and more accommodations on the Reserve, it is expected that more children will attend. The development of all of the Anaham Indian Reserve No. 1, possible with irrigation from the Chilcotin River, will also enable more of the Indians to stay at the village where the school is situated.

In my opinion, the ideal arrangement would be that two small dormitories be provided, one for boys and another for girls, to hold six beds in each dormitory, to accommodate pupils while their parents are at the meadows. I wish it clearly understood that this would not change the status of this school into a Residential School, as the Indians would be asked to contribute food, such as meat and vegetables, and the Sisters could have the Family Allowance payments to purchase the extra food recommended. There is a resident priest on the Reserve now—Father P. Brown, O.M.I., and this has been discussed with him and also the Missionary Sisters of Christ the King, who would be prepared to arrange for the supervision necessary. This idea might be extended to include Indian children from outside Reserves such as Nemaiah Valley, Stone and Toosey, depending upon what the Department proposes to do about the Cariboo Indian Residential School, which will be more fully discussed in a separate report.

My reason for going somewhat into details is so that the Department may decide what kind of a building is required and so that they can plan it for an extension when this is considered necessary, if not now, at some future date.

At present, there are twenty-nine pupils on the register of the junior room, in grades 1A, 1B,
and kindergarten, which is a heavy class of beginners, considering that they have to be taught a new language. There are 18 pupils in the senior room, mostly in grades two and three.

The minimum requirements, then, would be two classrooms, with possibilities for an additional classroom at an early date. The school building proper, erected at Bella Bella and Kitimat, would be satisfactory at Anaham with a full basement, providing possibilities for two rooms in the basement, one of which could be a manual training room and the other an additional classroom and club room.

Adjoining the school building would be the Sisters' Residence with kitchen, living room, four bedrooms, bathroom and dispensary. Part of this could form a wing so that the building would be an "L" shape, and provision could be made for the dormitories and/or two rooms for emergency hospital patients as desired.

I might say that Sr. Mary St. Paul, R.N., has made the services of Mrs. Anderson, R.N., at Alexis Creek unnecessary, with the exception that the hospital accommodation there provides for emergency cases from Redstone Reserve. Most of the patients who formerly were admitted from Anaham Reserve, are now taken care of in their own houses by Sr. Mary St. Paul. Mrs. Anderson, R.N., is continually complaining about the lack of patients for the Chilcotin Hospital, apparently forgetting that the Department had no idea of hospitalizing Indian patients there at all without the services of a resident physician. Mrs. E. Anderson is a very good nurse, but is, of course, not in a position, since she lives seven miles from the nearest Reserve, to give the same service as Sr. Mary St. Paul. In these circumstances, I would recommend that two rooms accommodating three beds each be included in the new building to take care of emergency cases.

With the appointment of a full-time Indian Doctor for this Agency, of course, it might be found more economical to hospitalize medical cases as distinct from surgical in the Chilcotin, but it is recommended that the Department have their own Hospital on Anaham Reserve in conjunction with the School.

While the Department may not be able to finance the construction of a building as indicated this
year, I thought it well to give my ideas of what is required, since it is much more economical to plan for expansion than to build two or three buildings, each with a separate heating plant, and so on, later on.

The Missionary Sisters of Christ the King have made it possible for a different set-up at Anaham than would be the rule in most day schools. The ultimate idea is to educate Indians girls so that they will be able to graduate as nurses, teachers and social workers amongst their own people. While this program would seem rather ambitious at present, among the Indians in this district, a beginning has to be made sometime, and, in the meantime much valuable social work as well as educational and medical service, is being given by the Order. I think I could also state that any work undertaken by these Sisters would be done more economically than by any other Agency since they are not primarily in hospitalization as a business to the extent that St. Paul's or the other large Catholic Hospitals in the country.

In conclusion, I would respectfully suggest that consideration is given to these ideas before a school building is began at Anaham, and I think that the Department should also get in touch with the head of the Missionary Sisters of Christ the Kind,—

Sister Mary of the Sacred Heart, N.C.R.,
60 Spadina Road,
Toronto, Ontario

who has given me the impression of being a very capable and practical lady with modern ideas.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.

I have your letter of the 13th instant, enclosing a communication from Indian Agent Christie with reference to suitable accommodation that he considers necessary on the Anaham Indian Reserve.

While Mr. Christie has submitted a very comprehensive report, I agree with the statement made in the last paragraph of your letter, that the matter will have to remain in abeyance for the time being. No funds were specifically provided in the current year's appropriation for the erection of a new school on the Anaham Reserve.

The suggestion made by Mr. Christie, that small dormitories be provided for a limited number of boys and girls, is a proposal that has been submitted to us from other points in the Dominion. Whether Mr. Christie realizes it or not, the provision of such accommodation would actually mean a small residential school. I think you will agree that we would have all the problems with a small group that we would have with a much larger group. A special staff would have to be engaged to look after the children during their free time and adequate provision would have to be made for sleeping accommodation, as well as meals, etc. The use of Family Allowances in the manner suggested by Mr. Christie would not be feasible. The basic thought in the payment of family allowances is to provide certain extras for children. The amount is certainly not sufficient to provide for their full maintenance in an institution, if an institution were established, as suggested by the Indian Agent.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I am forwarding herewith for the information of the Department a letter received from Mr. Indian Agent Christie in which he makes certain suggestions with respect to the provision of suitable accommodation for educational and medical requirements at the Ansham Indian Reserve.

The site which the Indians have agreed to surrender for school purposes is a very desirable one, being located close to the village and providing sufficient space for a playground and the development of a large school garden. Covering resolution of the Band, agreeing to the surrender of the area required, is enclosed.

Provision was made in the Post-War Program of Worthwhile Works for a two classroom school with a teacher's residence and no doubt the Department will proceed with the construction of a suitable building as soon as conditions become favourable.

Agent Christie's proposals are as follows:

(1) A two classroom block with provision for an additional room when required.

(2) A teacher's residence, including accommodation for a dispensary, dormitories for the housing of children whose parents for various reasons are not in continuous residence on the Reserve, and two rooms for use as an outpost hospital.
It is not clear from Mr. Christie's letter whether the services he refers to should be housed in one building or a group of buildings.

I feel that these matters can be held in abeyance until a full-time medical officer fills the vacancy existing since the retirement of Dr. McQuarrie, and the appointment of a School Inspector is made.

D. N. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

September 6, 1947.

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Director of Indian Affairs,
Indian Department,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

When I was in Ottawa this summer I mentioned to you the question of the proposed new school at Anahim and you turned to Mr. Neary and asked him to put that first on the schools for 1948. This school will need to be serviced with water from outside the village.

In looking over the sight for the proposed new school we found it necessary to move back some distance from the church because of solid rock which we encountered a few feet under the earth and consequently moved back to the proposed sight as marked on the enclosed Map. If you would like to return the map for our records it would be appreciated.

Near the proposed school we placed the novitiate, for the training of Indian girls, which was built by the Sisters of Christ the King who now teach in the school.

The girls who will come to this novitiate have been selected from the different Catholic Residential schools of the province, recommended by their Missionaries and by the Sisters who have had charge of them, and will be prepared by special instruction and training, hoping to obtain among them some teachers, social workers and nurses. The novitiate will cost in the vicinity of $25,000 which is being financed by the Church for the benefit of the Indian people.

Now, I am writing you to see if the pipelines necessary for the new school could not be brought in at the present time so that we could make use of it for the new novitiate. The Oblate Fathers in charge and the Sisters of Christ the King and our office here will appreciate very much your consideration of this project which, while perhaps in advance of the plans of the Department, will eventually be a part of their own work. You might like to refer the matter for consideration to Major MacKay, the Commissioner here, whom I am confident, because he knows the area so well, can furnish any other necessary information in the interest of the Indian people or of the Department.

I hope you are keeping well and have had a little rest from your many duties during the summer months. With kind regards to Mr. Neary and assuring you of our appreciation of the direction of the Department, I remain as ever

Very sincerely yours,

W. M. Duke
Archbishop of Vancouver

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Your File 160-2-1 (W.T.)

I have your letter of September 12th in which you refer to a communication received from Archbishop Duke in which His Excellency suggests that if at all possible the pipe line for the proposed new Departmental Day School at Ansham Indian Reserve, Williams Lake Agency, be installed immediately in order that water may be available to the institution for the training of Indian girls being constructed by the Sisters of Christ the King.

On receipt of your letter I discussed the matter with the Surveys and Engineering Branch and enclose herewith a copy of their reply dated September 25th from which it will be noted that both wood stave and iron pipe are in short supply and that the earliest date for supply of the former is March, 1948, and in the case of the latter promise of early delivery could not be secured. Under the circumstances and bearing in mind that construction is out of the question once frost penetrates the ground to any depth, it is most unlikely that the pipe line referred to could be installed until the coming spring. It therefore appears that it will be necessary for the Sisters to make the best arrangements possible to secure the water required from the existing system for the time being.

The sketch referred to in the last paragraph of your letter is being returned herewith.
