AIR MAIL.

Ottawa, April 19, 1948.

PERSONAL:

Dear Bill:

On Friday last Charlie Buck and I went with Emmett Morris to thoroughly inspect the new Chenail School. As you know, this is the two room school built to the plan sent you recently. We found the building entirely satisfactory and the contractor has done a very good job. Mr. Morris was particularly interested in the minor modifications which can be made in the plan so that he can make these minor improvements at Lennox Island. I would say that the following minor details are ones on which improvements can be made:

(1) If steel beams are obtainable, then the posts in the basement can be eliminated and you will find that the two basement rooms will be much better for future classroom use.

(2) The windows in the kitchen and living room downstairs are rather small and Mr. Buck is going to improve them (this will take some time as they are absolutely swamped with work).

(3) The stairs from the teacher's living quarters can be straightened out to remove the landing. This will allow more space in the living room and also will give you to take furniture upstairs more easily. The contractor has been able to do this at Chenail by putting in fourteen steps and raising them to 8" apart.
The classrooms are just perfect and I am sure that Bob Davey will be very pleased with them. Of course, we installed flush toilets, running water and electricity at Chenail as a result we have a very modern and satisfactory school.

I was discussing the situation with Mr. Buck on the way home and we agreed that perhaps you would like to look at another two room school plan which has been especially developed for the Northwest Territories. There we can not put in a basement because of the perma-frost. The attached blueprint is only a preliminary drawing and changes will be made. I brought to the Architect's attention the fact that the fenestration is not sufficient for our needs. This is due to the fact that Mr. McKinnon specifically asked for folding doors between the two classrooms so that it could be used as a community hall. This meant that they were unable to work in windows along the other side wall. However, I would ask you to look it over and let me have it back. If you feel that it would be better for your needs at Anaham and Hazelton then I can arrange to have you sent the final plans.

I hope everything is going well with Mrs. Arneil and yourself and that you are both finding Vancouver to your liking. As you probably know I have had Betty out visiting my people in Victoria and she is now on her way home.

As ever,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Indian Commissioner,

Re: Anaham Indian Day School

With reference to Mr. Hoey's letter of March 23rd the plans of the Department's standard two-room Indian Day school with attached teachers residence were reviewed with Archbishop Duke and with Mr. E. J. Boughen, the contractor who built the Convent at Anaham. Mr. Boughen has just returned from a visit to the Williams Lake Agency during the course of which he discussed with the teachers of the Anaham Indian Day School and with Mr. Indian Agent Christie the requirements in the way of accommodation for the former. The following changes to the basis plan are suggested and submitted to the Department for consideration following which we shall secure a tender on labour:

1. Mr. Boughen has suggested, and I concur, that it would be advisable to make the stair wells on each end of the building of slow burning construction.

2. Provision of fire exits with panic bolts from each cloakroom with fire escapes to the ground.

3. Installation of a unit to provide forced air heating to the basement rooms and other rooms if necessary.

4. Extension of the section of the building providing First Aid and Dispensary accommodation in the basement and living quarters on the first and second floors a distance of approximately six feet to provide sufficient
floor area on the second floor to permit of a minimum of three bedrooms for the Sisters, one of whom, Sister Mary St. Paul, R.N., is employed by the Indian Health Services as Field Matron.

(5) Extension of the building as above referred will provide sufficient floor space for the installation of a flush toilet and bath in the second floor living quarters. In addition it is proposed to install a flush toilet, one two-part urinal and two showers in the basement for the boys and three toilets and two showers for the girls. I may say that the pipeline serving the Convent passes within one hundred feet of the school site and provision of the sanitary facilities referred to is strongly recommended.

A proposed arrangement with the Church whereby they supply the school with water in return for the provision of electricity on a metered basis to the Convent from the plant to be installed in the school will be the subject of a separate communication. I might mention that water pressure from the church system is 28 pounds on the second floor of the Convent and will be adequate for the operation of flush toilets.

Mr. Boughen, according to information we have, has an excellent foreman, Iver Hottlien, who would carry out construction with local labour under the supervision of Mr. Christie and on receipt of the Department's decision of the changes above listed he will be asked to submit a tender for labour and Mr. Boughen will prepare a list of materials apart from lumber which can be provided by the Agency sawmill and tenders will be called for on this basis. A reply in due course would be appreciated.

W.S. Amos,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
June 10, 1948.

Anaham Indian Day School

Reference your 17-11-3 of June 4, 1948.

The Department is willing to consider Mr. Boughen's recommendations concerning the slow burning stair wells. The provision of fire exits from this school, as suggested, has not been considered necessary elsewhere because of the fact that this is a day school and not a residential school.

We are prepared to consider the extension recommended by Mr. Boughen but we have only a sum of $28,000.00 in our estimates for the construction of this school. We have found elsewhere that if we start making major changes in the plans of the school the expenditure increases by leaps and bounds. However, this school is so designed that flush toilets, etc., can be installed in that part of the building marked "First Aid Room and Dispensary". We can send you a marked plan which will indicate how this was done at the Chenail School on the St. Regis Reserve. By enlarging the chemical closet room on the second floor we were also able to provide a toilet and shower for the teachers.

Mr. Boughen can submit a labour tender or we can pay Mr. Holtlien on a day labour basis.

Bernard E. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Anaham Indian Day School

I have delayed replying to Mr. Neary's Army Signals message of May 20th regarding the provision of accommodation for the Sisters at the Anaham Reserve in our new Day School building pending an opportunity of discussing the matter with Dr. P.S. Tennant. I have now ascertained from Dr. Tennant that Sister Mary St. Paul is not employed full time by the Indian Health Services and that consequently they are not committed to provide accommodation for her and therefore it presumably is not necessary for us to consider the requirements of the Indian Health Services in our school construction program, particularly as accommodation for Sisters other than our two teachers should be available in the noviciate building if not in the present day school building where the nursing station referred to is apparently established.

I might mention however it is my understanding there is another Sister at Anaham who I believe looks after the housekeeping needs of the two teachers and possibly the Department would wish to provide accommodation for her.

GENERAL ELECTRICAL SPECIFICATIONS.

1. All clauses of the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this trade.

2. Scope of Work

The Contractor shall supply all materials required and shall install, in a thorough and workmanlike manner, a system of electric wiring as shown on accompanying electrical plan.

Provide all conduit, wire, cable, fittings, panels, switches, lighting fixtures, wiring devices and all appurtenances necessary for a complete and approved system ready for operation.

3. Rules and Regulations

All work shall be carried out in accordance with the rules and regulations as set forth in the Canadian Electrical Code together with such additional regulations of the local Inspection Authorities as may be applicable. Before final payment on contract is authorized a certificate of inspection and approval of work from the Inspection Department of the local authorities shall be submitted to the Chief Engineer. The Contractor shall file all necessary plans with the local authorities and pay all fees and take out all permits in connection therewith.

4. Visit the Site

The Contractor must visit the site and see the conditions under which the work is to be done and all electrical work shall be planned and done in close cooperation with the workmen performing work of the other trades.
5. Material and Workmanship

All materials and workmanship shall be the best of their respective kinds. All pipes and fittings shall be galvanized. Lighting panels shall be galvanized and finished in black baked-on enamel. Materials shall be new and as detailed on plan and/or as herein specified. Substitutions will be permitted only by written approval of the Chief Engineer. Studs and joists must not be notched or otherwise cut except by drilled holes centred in wood members.

6. Wiring

Except as noted on plan and/or as herein specified the wiring shall be done in 600 volt maximum rubber insulated braid covered wire enclosed in rigid galvanized conduit concealed in ceiling, wall and floor construction. Wiring shown in basement floor slab shall be lead covered cable enclosed in rigid galvanized steel conduit of size noted on plan. Feeder from service switch to lighting panel shall be run exposed.

All wiring shall be done according to Canadian Electrical Code regulations governing this type of installation.

7. Painting and Labelling

GENERAL PLUMBING SPECIFICATIONS.

1. SCOPE OF WORK

This specification and the accompanying plans are intended to provide for a complete plumbing and drainage installation and fire protection service in the school building and the Contractor shall furnish all material and labour of every description required therefor for its proper completion.

2. VISIT THE SITE

The Contractor shall visit the site and see the conditions under which the work will be done and govern himself accordingly.

3. RULES AND REGULATIONS

All work shall be done in accordance with rules, regulations and recommendations as may be laid down by local or other authorities controlling such work. The contractor shall file all necessary plans with such authorities and pay all necessary fees for permits, etc., as may be required.

4. MATERIALS AND WORKMANSHIP

All materials shall be new and the best of their respective kinds.

All work shall be executed in a neat and workmanlike manner by workers skilled in this trade, and special attention shall be given exposed work so that it be neatly erected with pipes plumb and true.

5. EXCAVATING AND BACKFILLING

Contractor shall do all necessary excavating and backfill after same incident to the installation of his work. Backfilling will be done in shallow layers and be thoroughly puddled and tamped.

6. ROUGHING IN

Furnish and install complete lines of drains, vents, wastes, etc., of required sizes. All fixtures shall be back vented as noted on drawings or as may be required.

Install water lines and make all necessary connections to fixtures. Each plumbing fixture shall have air chambers installed on both hot and cold water lines, such air chambers being not less than 12" long. All branch lines shall be separately valved.

7. DRAINAGE UNDERFLOOR

All soil and drain pipe below the basement floor shall be extra heavy cast iron with bell and spigot ends. The inside of such pipe shall be clean and free from rust and shall be thoroughly oiled inside and out to give a protective coating.
8. EXPOSED DRAINS

All soil and drain pipe above the basement floor shall be medium weight cast iron with bell and spigot ends, and shall be clean and free from rust and shall be thoroughly oiled inside and out.

9. JOINTS

All joints in cast iron pipe shall be made with oakum and molten lead and thoroughly caulked.

All joints in waste or vent piping shall be made with long sweep recessed cast iron drain fittings.

Where screwed joints are used for soil or waste pipe, they shall have a smooth continuous interior surface.

Joints to fixtures shall be made with proper gaskets and ferrules as required.

Water closets shall be connected to soil drains by means of brass or cast iron floor flange not less than \( \frac{3}{16} \) inch thick with caulked joints to cast iron soil drain and with approved packing ring.

10. GRADING OF PIPES

Waste and soil piping shall be graded in the direction of flow with a pitch of not less than \( \frac{1}{4} \) inch to the foot unless otherwise noted on plan or specified.

All horizontal branches of vent piping shall be graded with the same pitch as above toward the fixtures.

All horizontal branches of hot and cold water piping shall be so graded that they may be completely drained through drip connections installed at necessary points.

11. CLEANOUTS

Provide and set fittings in all drain and soil pipes for cleanouts at all points where obstruction might occur and at the ends of all long horizontal pipes and all points required by-laws, or as directed or shown on drawings. Also install Barrett cleanouts at feet of all stacks.

Cleanouts shall be full size for pipes up to 4" diameter and not less than 1" for larger pipes. In horizontal runs they shall be closed gas-tight with heavy brass ferrules caulked in and capped with screw cap, and where on drains underground shall finish flush with floor.
12. WATER PIPING

Cold water piping included in this contract shall begin at a point 3'-0" outside of the building, or otherwise as noted on plans.

All domestic hot and cold water piping in this building shall be galvanized steel standard weight, put together with galvanized screwed malleable iron fittings. No cold water piping shall be laid in any floor slab. Water service pipes within the basement shall be covered as hereafter described, and exposed to view on external walls and below ceilings.

13. HANGERS

Standing runs of cast iron pipe shall be securely fixed in position by means of strong iron supports placed immediately below the hubs.

Horizontal runs of cast iron pipe shall be supported by means of hand iron hanger rings and 3/8 in ch rod supports from the ceiling.

Vertical runs of water pipe shall be supported by means of iron supports same as for cast iron pipes.

Horizontal runs of water piping shall be supported at 8'6" intervals with rod and ring hangers. No grabbler bar hangers allowed.

14. VALVES

Valves generally shall be gate valves unless otherwise mentioned. 2" and under shall be all brass. Over 2" shall be iron body valves with bronze trimmings.

15. FLASHING

Where vent stacks project through the roof they shall be suitably cap flashed with 5 lb. lead to make a satisfactory and watertight job.

16. TESTING

Water Piping: Contractor will test all water piping before covering, using cold water at 100 lb. pressure.

Drains and vent system shall be tested for leakage by being filled with water to roof level.

Underfloor drains shall be tested for grade using a standard billiard ball.

On completion of the work the sanitary system shall be submitted to a smoke test.

17. SLEEVES AND ESCUTCHEONS

Where exposed pipes pass through floors, partitions or ceilings in finished rooms, they shall be provided with galvanized iron sleeves 1/2 inch larger than the pipe and cast iron or chrome plated pressed steel escutcheons either of the one piece or split ring type.

Carpenters can be secured at $1.50 an hour, White labourers at $1.00 an hour and Indian helpers at $6.00 a day. Mr. Arneil points out that it is essential that the construction commence immediately so that the building can be completed before winter. He is anxious to have authority to proceed with the work on the basis suggested in this memorandum.

I would appreciate it if the Minister would approve the construction of the building by day labour with Mr. Holtbein as foreman at the rates stated above.

Director.

Re: Anaham Indian Day School - Electrical contract

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of October 20th (file 160-2-5 E), the Jarvis Electric Company tender has been discussed with them and an amended tender, enclosed herewith, secured. According to the Company, material and labour costs have increased 15% since the date of their original tender of July 7th and their tender for the provision of labour and material necessary for wiring the building according to plan for acceptance now is $1,173. It does not include starting batteries (two 6-volt storage batteries are required for the plant quoted on) and the Department would be required to provide travelling expenses, room and board and pay additional wages to the Company's electricians for travelling time.

I understand the Jarvis Electric Company have been awarded the contracts for wiring in several public buildings in Vancouver, including the Unemployment Insurance Commission building and from information available it would appear that
their work is satisfactory. Their tender is considerably lower than that of Mott Electric. As intimated in my letter of October 20th, construction of the new school has proceeded to the point where it is essential that the contracts for heating and wiring be placed immediately and I trust that the Purchasing Agent will now be in a position to decide to whom the electrical contract should be awarded.

I am enclosing for your information a copy of letter dated March 21st, 1949, from Mr. E.J. Boughen, who supervised the construction of the above-mentioned School building. You will note that the building is nearing completion and apart from a few details of minor nature, will likely be completed by April 1st.

Dear Mr. Arneil,

I have just returned last Friday evening from a trip of inspection to the school at Anahim Flat Reserve.

I found the work proceeding quite satisfactorily. The foreman, Iver Holtlien, and myself judged it would be possible to complete the job, barring unforeseen contingencies, by the last of April with the men we have on the job now.

I made a report, on the official documents in Mr. Christie's hands, of the electrical wiring, etc., the electric generator and the forced warm air, automatic conditioning heating system all of which I found complete and in good working order.

The plumbing should be completed in a week or so. All the piping, wastes and vents are installed but not as yet tested. Four of fifteen plumbing fixtures are installed. Most of the other fixtures' installation is delayed by the frost still being in some of the basement so that it has not been advisable to lay the concrete floor on it, as yet.

I attempted to check the accounts on this school that are in Mr. Christie's hands when I was in Williams Lake but it was too big an undertaking for the time at my disposal there, so Mr. Christie allowed me to bring them down. I have checked them over and made up a complete summary of costs and returned the accounts, etc., to Mr. Christie by registered mail. I am enclosing a copy of my summary to you.

In July, 1948, I made an estimate of probable costs which amounted to $27,934.00 but which did not include the common lumber (which we had expected to get from the mill on the Stone Reserve) and freight on same and the hardware, costs of which I did not have. Paints & Electric fixtures also were not included as I was not certain what instructions I would receive in this connection. These items total up to $4570.00 making a grand total of $32,504.00. Actually the cost of the building, according to my Summary of Mar. 19th
W.S. Arneil, Ind. Comm.
(2) Mar. 21st/49

will be, if $2500.00 completes it,-and it should,-$33,690,
or about 4% over my original cost list. The bill for trucking
appears to be heavy,-considerably beyond my estimate. The
cost of the gravel for concrete was too high and of course we
lost considerable through avoidable and un-avoidable delays,
including $213.00 added to the original electric wiring and
generator plant tender.

I am of the opinion that better results might
have been obtained if all invoices, etc. had been mailed to
Mr. Christie, c/o myself 1529 West 65th so that I could check
them against the original order.

Naturally I would be in a better position to
check quantities and costs than could Mr. Christie or Iver
Holtlien the foreman (Mr. Christie had him sign the bills).

I requested the Reliance Lbr. Co. last summer
to supply me with a list of the material they were to supply
with the prices. I got the list of material but the prices
were cut off. Their total bill for finish lumber, wallboard,
Bestolite and Masonite proved to be $416.00 higher than I
estimated from prices I had got for the Novitiate (principally
from the Valley Lbr. Yards and Mohawk Lbr. Co. & Can. Western
Lbr. Co.)

Of course there may have been some increase in
prices in the meantime.

It is in my mind that when we were discussing
the probable cost of the school last June & July you asked me
if I thought the total cost would be $35,000.00 and I said I
felt sure the cost would not go over that amount. If that is
correct (I do not know, of course, what amount the Dept. set
aside for the school) I am still $1200.00 or $1300.00 below
that figure.

Right here I wish to thank you, your office staff
and Mr. Christie for the consideration and assistance they have
so willingly given me at all times in connection with this
building. Mr. Christie is quite evidently proud of the build-
ing and says Anahim Flat Reserve will be the show place of the
Cariboo and moreover that you should arrange your schedule to
include giving the school your official blessing at the opening.

Yours very truly, Edmund J. Boughen Sgd.

March 26, 1949

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Department,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Major MacKay:

It was always a pleasure when you were here to make a contact with you and have a quiet chat about our common problems.

The following problem presents itself now, and I felt like writing to you personally about it.

Last spring we made arrangements with the Department in connection with the new school near the new Novitiate at Anaham by which to save the Department getting water themselves we would supply the water from the Novitiate supply and in return the Novitiate would be supplied with light from the school.

However, the cost of the water is much higher than the cost of supplying the light. The total cost was approximately $5,000.00.

As you know, we had to bring the water in about 2200 feet from the side of the mountain.

As all this work is in the interests of the Indian people for whom the Sisters of Christ the King have already made great sacrifices, I would appreciate it if you could possibly take care of this account, and thus help us in the work which we have been carrying on in that Indian territory which you know so well and which you have helped ever since coming into the Department.

With kind personal regards and every good wish,

I remain

Very sincerely yours,

W. M. Duke
Archbishop of Vancouver.

Immediately upon receipt of your army message I went to see the Director concerning the matter of the electricity and water supply at this school. It is very difficult, naturally, to settle these matters by long distance correspondence and therefore I would suggest that either yourself or Major Davey interview Archbishop Dako and advise him of the cost of installing the electrical plant. It is evident from his letter that he believes the water supply cost more than the electrical supply. As you are aware (your letter 17-11-3 (167) of March 22) the electrical plant has cost as follows:

The Director does not wish to have the Department obligated to the Church. I would suggest, therefore, that after discussing this matter with the Archbishop, we be advised as to what settlement would be mutually agreeable to both yourself and him.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Fencing - Anaham Indian Day School

Superintendent Christie has advised that it will be necessary to fence the school and grounds, in order to protect the windows from horses and other animals on the Reserve and to establish the boundaries of the school site, thus preventing encroachment by, and consequent difficulty with, band members who may wish to establish themselves too close to the school.

The cost of labour and material for the fence is estimated at approximately $410.00, $200.00 of which is for labour.

While I am most anxious to avoid the unnecessary expenditure of funds from Vote 516, Allotment 13, the erection of the fence in this case would appear to be a necessity. I would recommend that the Department approve the expenditure required and that an accountable advance of $200.00 be forwarded to Mr. Christie. The required funds which are in addition to the $3,164.00 necessary to complete the school building, might be transferred from the appropriation for the Alberni classroom block.

W.S. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

In the meantime, we are forwarding Superintendent Christie an advance of $200.00 which he recommends.

Re: Electric Lighting Plant - Anaham Indian Day School

I am forwarding Superintendent Christie's letter of October 26th and subsequent letters dated November 3rd and 16th, from which you will note that the above-mentioned plant was extensively damaged due to over-heating.

Mr. Christie's letters infer that the damage was due to a lack of proper ventilation in the room housing the plant and while this may have been a contributing factor I feel that lack of attention on the part of those operating the plant may have been the main reason why the damage occurred, and for this reason have been in no hurry to secure authority for the necessary repairs.

You will note that Mr. Christie recommends the erection of a small building separate from the school building, to house the plant so that adequate ventilation can be secured. I feel that the room in which the plant is presently housed could be adequately ventilated with an exhaust fan but concur with his suggestion for the reason that space occupied by the plant could be used to greater advantage for storing fuel.

I would recommend that the Department endeavour to make funds available to the extent of approximately $305.00 for the erection of a separate building to house the plant, and $180.00 for repairs to the plant.

Re: Lighting plant - Anaham School

In reply to your letter of November 12th, we have now been able to get an estimate of the cost of repairs to the above-mentioned Plant. It will cost approximately $125.00 for repairs and $55.00 for labour, a total of $180.00.

The following repairs are required:

4 connecting rods, complete with bearings and shims
1 crank shaft
1 complete set main bearings and shims
1 set main bearing caps
1 set main bearing cap screws
1 set rings STD.
1 complete set gaskets

With further reference to the building for this Plant, I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Boughen, a copy of which is enclosed. You will note that Mr. Boughen considers that the bearings burned out on account of lack of oil, presumably because the room door was closed and the engine overheated. After all the only reason for having a fireproof door on the Engine Room was to prevent fire and therefore the door should be closed to comply with fire regulations.

Furthermore, Mr. Boughen designed the building and supervised its construction and made several inspection trips to see that everything was as it should be.

The only reason I am sending you a copy of Mr. Boughen's letter, however, is because he does not favour a separate building. It is quite true that a separate building will cost more money but Mr. Iver Holtlien, who was foreman on construction of the School and also Jack Miller, who installed the lighting plant, both favour a separate building.

Dear Mr. Christie:

Just got a letter from Iver in which he says that more trouble has happened with the electrical equipment at Anahim School. That the engine bearings burned out on account of lack of oil presumably because the room door was closed and the engine overheated.

Seems like as though there is no responsible person there to see that even the simplest conditions are carried out.

Undoubtedly if the room was closed up the engine would overheat. But the bearings being burned out of the engine might be the lack of new oil being put in the engine at proper periods because that oil will stand tremendous heat if there is sufficient quantity in the pan.

When I was there about a month ago your Asst., Mr. Lees, mentioned a vent shown on the Plants which was not put in. He said it could be cut in the wall under the engine radiator.

Apparently this has not been cut in. Can you get Iver to do it, and put a piece of screen over the opening.

Iver said you were speaking about a shed outside where plenty of ventilation could be obtained.

We considered this in connection with the St. James School but it was my opinion that, - even with a small stove in it,- (which would probably be allowed to be without fuel some cold night anyway) would not be altogether fool proof either.

So the St. James School will be built with a 10 ft x 12 ft extension which will take in the back steps from the basement as well as the Electrical equipment with door into the main basement and heat from there also when necessary. It won't freeze up anyway. If you are going to put up a separate building for it I think it should be done along the same lines as the St. James School plans, but I do not think it necessary to do so. To make a new building and move the electrical equipment into it and connect up again is quite an undertaking.

I suggest that you have a vent cut in the wall and screened as I wrote above (about 20 in x 14 in) and if that is not enough (and I don't think it will be) get a suction electric fan put in the outside wall, near the ceiling, with a metal box into the elec. room. That will be easier to put in and will keep the room well ventilated at all times by having it connected so that whenever the plant is working the fan will also work. It will also be
vastly cheaper than an outside house, will be more nearly fool proof, and if they can keep water in the radiator and oil in the engine should give no more trouble. Will be glad to see about fan and piping if you decide to put it in that way.

I hope you will adopt my suggestion for the vent and the fan. It will be less trouble for you to get installed, will be fool-proof and will remedy the present trouble. I probably could get the fan assembly made up here, ship up to you as soon as ready. It could be put in by almost anyone.

If you build a shed for it there would always be the danger of it freezing up. Some one will let the fire go out in very cold water some time and even with anti-freeze in the radiator the plant would be too cold to start easily with the possible result of damage to something or exhaustion of the batteries.

Yours very truly,

"Edmund J. Boughen"

Re: Electric Lighting Plant
Anaham - Your File 17-5-2

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 15th instant regarding the lighting plant located in the school on Anaham Indian Reserve.

It is very much regretted that serious damage was done to this plant on October 15th. I have not written until today because I was waiting for the return of Mr. Lees, the Assistant, to find out exactly what damage had been done. He advises me that the following damage occurred to the plant, which has a Waukeshaw Motor, Model FC-182-A, No. 756632:

1. Three main bearings burned out.
2. Four connecting rods burned out.
3. Crankshaft scored.
4. Pistons seized.

It is also quite possible that the piston rings will have to be replaced and the cylinders may have to be honed out and the pistons polished; new head gaskets and new pan gaskets will also have to be supplied, the crankshaft will have to be machined and it may be advisable to get a new crankshaft.

I would suggest that the machine be brought into Williams Lake, which we can do in our truck and Mr. Lees can take the head off and find out whether the motor will have to be shipped to Vancouver or whether it can be repaired here with the replacement of the parts mentioned.

Mr. Lees is of the opinion that there was sufficient oil in the motor but it overheated causing the evaporation of the oil and that a flash fire took place in the pan. His opinion is based on examination of the parts and from statements received from the Sisters. The Sisters advise that on Saturday, October 15th, they turned on the plant about five o'clock, about 8.30 the lights started to die down and...
W. S. Arneil, Esq.  
26/10/49.

When they reached the plant it had already stopped and smoke was pouring from the engine. They also advise that the door of the power room had been closed by some of the children.

There is no doubt in my mind that a separate building will have to be erected for this plant. With this in mind I contacted Ivor Holtien, who has agreed to submit an estimate for material required for this building. It is suggested that the building be $12 \times 12$ or $12 \times 14$. When I have received the list of material required it will be submitted to you together with an estimate of cost of labour.

Mr. Lees, Assistant in this Agency, advises me that he could repair this motor providing the cylinders do not have to be honed out. However, if this has to be done I think it will be necessary to ship the head down to Vancouver.

Kindly advise me as soon as possible what you wish us to do in this matter toward getting the plant repaired.

Wm. Christie, Supt.,  
Williams Lake Indian Agency.

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of December 9th (file 871-5 E.1) in connection with outstanding accounts, Anishin Indian Day School, which exceed the amount which we advised would complete the structure, it is regretted that the amount transferred has been over-expended but you will realize that it is difficult if not impossible for either this office or the Indian Superintendent to check such estimates and we must necessarily be guided by the person in charge of the construction. As a matter of fact the over-expenditure is greater than the amount indicated in your letter for the reason that we were confronted recently with a statement from Mitchell Brothers, plumbing and heating contractors, which indicated an outstanding balance of $460.60 and enquiry revealed that the plan provided to Mitchell Brothers by Mr. Boughen showed the kitchen sink in a location which was in a later plan changed, necessitating the relocation of the rough plumbing for this fixture, the labour and material for which cost $109.98. This change was not brought to the attention of the plumber until after the rough plumbing was in and the change was made at the request of the building supervisor, Mr. Boughen or his foreman, Mr. Holtlien. The Company performed the work in good faith and are entitled to payment.

The other invoice, in the amount of $350.52, covers rough plumbing for the showers for the girl's and boy's washrooms, which installations were arranged by Mr. Boughen without authority from this office and in explanation of which he states he requested the plumber to rough in only that part of the installation which would be covered by concrete and that this was done in order to avoid the necessity of breaking up the concrete at a later date to install these facilities. I might mention at this time that in our opinion Mr. Boughen, in his capacity as erection supervisor, assumes more authority than he should and it is our intention if the school at Fort St. James is erected under his supervision to inform him prior to the commencement of construction that he will have to be personally responsible for unauthorized expenditures.

AIR MAIL

May 25th, 1950.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Anaham Indian Day School

Several weeks ago, Superintendent Christie forwarded to us a requisition for supplies for the above school. Included on the requisition was a request for 6 small and 6 medium sized desks.

As the Superintendent made no comment regarding this request, we wrote to him again and have received the following reply:

"The twelve desks requested by the teachers are necessary as at present they are using small tables and homemade seats for some of the children."

I am instructing Mr. Christie to write to you and if you concur in the above, you may arrange purchase of the twelve desks.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

W.S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Furnishings - Anaham Indian Day School - Teacherage

Attached are requisitions for furnishings for the teacherage, Anaham Indian Day School.

Quotations were obtained from all local firms and requisitions are based on price and quality.

In view of the fact that the floors have not been sanded the Sisters at Anaham recommended battleship linoleum or Marboleum to cover all the floor space. This would however necessitate the employment of an experienced Carpenter to lay same and would probably cost an additional $100.00. An alternative would be to purchase linoleum rugs but the Marboleum would last much longer.

A price was also got on a second hand Range in first class condition for the basement room it is proposed to teach Home Economics.

An item of $1000.00 was placed in the Estimates for 1949-50 for this purpose.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Furnishings - Anaham Indian Day School

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of April 30, 1938, regarding the establishment of an Indian Day School at Alexis Creek in the Williams Lake Agency, I enclose herewith copy of a survey of the situation made by Mr. Indian Agent Taylor, under cover of his letter of July 2, 1938, together with a letter dated July 4th, received from His Excellency Archbishop W.M. Duke of Vancouver, and Mr. Inspector Barry's report of the 6th ultimo, also letters from Mr. Taylor dated 12th and 23rd of July.

Perusal of this correspondence will show that the proposal is to erect a day school on Alexis Creek Indian Reserve No. 3 to provide accommodation for 40 pupils and teacher's quarters, the school to be operated from November 1 to March 31, during which period the Indians are on their cattle feeding grounds, the balance of the year being scattered over a wide area in connection with their cattle industry when it is not possible to bring the children together for tuition.

The question of whether funds could be provided for the construction and outfitting of the school and quarters and a teacher secured in time for opening a school for the coming winter is problematical, but it might be considered advisable to set aside $100 for the purpose of getting out the logs, in order to give them an opportunity of drying out before proceeding with the construction. It is probable that this could be attended to during next winter. Provision is being made in the 1941-42 estimates to build and furnish the structure in case funds are not available to proceed with construction during the present fiscal year.

Following a careful review of the subject with Mr. Taylor recently, the estimated costs were placed at

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of June 3rd, last regarding the suggested day school for the Alexis Creek Band, I enclose herewith a list of the children of this Band up to the age of sixteen years.

The distance at which families at present reside from suggested school site does not need to be taken into account as I am advised by all the parents that in the event of a school being erected, they are prepared to build houses in the immediate vicinity. These houses will not be clustered around the school building, but will be erected at distances varying from three hundred yards to within one mile on suitable sites.

At a meeting with the Alexis Creek Band this week, I find all of them still very anxious for the establishment of a school as soon as possible. They agree with me that a winter school operating from 1st November to the end of April is the most feasible solution as during the rest of the year they will be travelling in connection with the hunting, trapping and haying activities.

A log building is considered most suitable for a school and the Indians are prepared to cut and haul logs to the school site in return for rations, no wages being expected. The same would apply to the building of a log house for the accommodation of the teacher.

It would be necessary for the Department to supply lumber, doors, windows and roofing material, etc., for both buildings.
There are competent carpenters in the Band who could complete construction of the buildings on a food ration basis. Lumber can be secured locally at a distance of within fifty miles.

It might be considered advisable to secure a married male teacher, whose wife would be available to supervise the children in their homes and possibly render elementary medical attention when necessary, as it might be difficult at times during the winter for a doctor to get in there.

The matter of a suitable water supply was enquired into and I am advised that there are suitable springs which would give an adequate supply of good water although some piping may be necessary.

As you will see from the attached list there are seventy-eight children up to the age of sixteen years practically none of whom are at present able to secure any schooling. I may say that the Indians are opposed to the idea of a residential or semi-residential school being established in the vicinity of the Anaham Reserve.

Many of the parents have already built cabins in the vicinity of the suggested school site and even if all of them do not carry out their promise to build in the vicinity of the school, I am satisfied that there will be a sufficient attendance to justify the erection of the school.

Some of the Indians intimated that it would be necessary for the Department to supply them with lumber and other building material to complete the erection of their log dwellings.

If you contemplate a visit to the suggested school site this year, I would suggest Priest Time in October as the most suitable time, as the haying will then be finished and most of the Indians will be assembled to meet their priest.

Yours very truly,

H.E. Taylor,
Indian Agent.

Indian Commissioner,
P.O.Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

In a letter dated the 4th instant His Excellency Archbishop Duke informs me that on a recent visit to the Cariboo he found at Redstone 42 children of school age from 6 to 16 years of age, without school facilities, and also 20 children from 1 to 6 years of age, and that all these children live within twelve miles of the proposed site of the school, should one be authorized.

His Excellency mentions the Chezacuz Meadows as a good site for a school, and offers to have Rev. Father Hennessy meet me in the Cariboo if I could go up there in the Fall to see the place.

There has as you know been some correspondence with regard to the establishment of such a school, and I would refer you in particular to the Department's decision in letter 160-82-1 that I was not to make a special trip into Redstone to conduct a school survey. Though I have been twice at Williams Lake since the receipt of the above mentioned letter from the Department, I have on neither occasion been able to arrange for the special and rather long motor trip into the Redstone country.

On July 6th 1938 I forwarded to you, with reference to the distribution of pupils from Coqualeetza School, a proposed building programme to cover the Fiscal Years 1939 to 1942. For a number of reasons, particularly perhaps because the Redstone children live at such distances from a common centre at present, and also because they are all over the country on hay meadows in the summer months, but also because provision had to be made during the years mentioned for the education of children who otherwise would have gone to Coqualeetza I could not include the proposed Redstone school in that proposed building programme.

I am forwarding herewith a letter from Indian Agent Taylor dated July 2 1938 and his list of children available then. The ages of the children must now be advanced two years in each case.

May I particularly draw your attention to the suggestion contained in Mr Taylor's letter, Paragraph 3, that the school should be a seasonal one for six months from November 1st to April 30th, and also to the suggestion in Paragraph 4 that the necessary buildings be of log construction.

If a log building is erected it should certainly be large enough to accommodate 40 pupils. Small log buildings are not suitable for school purposes.
The Department may wonder why I have not previously recommended the establishment of an Indian day school at Redstone.

I have been very doubtful with regard to the wisdom of gathering Indians together into a new village just to make it possible for the children to attend a day school. It is of course obvious that no school could be a success at Redstone unless the Indians did build new houses in a central location. As you will see from the second last paragraph of Mr. Taylor's letter even now some of the Indians are looking to the Department for assistance in the completion of their proposed new houses.

I have felt that it might well be better to permit the Indians to continue their present mode of life, that of active trapping, hunting, and haying.

As these occupations take up almost all the year I did not see just how we should be able to keep up anything like a satisfactory average attendance at the school.

However I may be quite wrong in this case and have therefore gone into the whole matter again with care, considering the lists of children, the Indian Agent's recommendations, the Archbishop's letter etc.

Provided the Indians in return for rations, etc., erect under the supervision of a competent person a large log building for a school and a smaller building for a teacher's residence, and the Department can find sufficient funds to provide the lumber, windows, doors, roofing, inside finishing, etc., as well as material for rough homemade desks, blackboards etc., I am now prepared to recommend the establishment of a seasonal school at Redstone.

I consider that a five month's school during the winter, that is from November 1st to March 31st would be all that these Indians could make proper use of, and this type of school would be in line with other seasonal schools.

I am not very well and do not believe that the strain of a journey into Redstone would be worth while in any case. My travelling has been limited by instructions from the Department. The site chosen by the Indian Agent is no doubt a suitable one, and a special trip to Redstone does not appear to me to be necessary just to confirm his findings. Should such a school be established I would of course do my best to get in there at least once to see that the teacher understood what was necessary, though such seasonal schools are not in the usual way inspected by me.

Within the limits suggested above I would recommend the establishment of the seasonal school asked for by His Excellency Archbishop Duke.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
646 Richards St.
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Captain Barry:

On my visit to the Cariboo, I found at Redstone Reserve 42 children of school age from 6 to 16 years of age without school facilities, and also 20 children from 1 to 6 years of age to ensure a future to the school, all the children living within twelve miles.

A good site for a day school would be Chezacuz Meadows. Father Hennessy thought you might be able, perhaps, to go up there in the fall and see the place yourself, and I will make arrangements for him to meet you whenever it is convenient.

On my recent visit to Enderby on Confirmation tour, I found a number of Indian Children not attending school and it was the opinion of Fr. Cullinan as well as my own, that a day school at Enderby would do a lot of good and would have a great influence on the Indian families and children.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report on the present school situation in the Williams Lake Indian Agency showing the number of Indian children in the Agency who are not provided with any facilities for acquiring an education.

The following is a statement of the children, of school age, of pre-school age, attending the Cariboo Residential School, and the percentage of school age children attending school:

| Band            | School Age | Pre-School Age | Registered at Cariboo Indian School |
|-----------------|------------|----------------|-------------------------------------|
| Alexis Creek    | 36         | 29             | 0                                   |
| Abraham         | 78         | 47             | 18                                  |
| Alexandria      | 10         | 9              | 9                                   |
| Alkali Lake     | 38         | 31             | 24                                  |
| Canoe Lake      | 27         | 23             | 15                                  |
| Canoe Creek     | 41         | 23             | 12                                  |
| Clinton         | 8          | 2              | 3                                   |
| Quesnel         | 5          | 3              | 0                                   |
| Soda Creek      | 27         | 15             | 15                                  |
| Stone           | 24         | 8              | 3                                   |
| Tossey          | 13         | 9              | 13                                  |
| Williams Lake   | 33         | 20             | 21                                  |
| Nemiah Valley   | 18         | 18             | 2                                   |
| High Bar        | 1          | 1              | 0                                   |
| **Totals**      | **359**    | **238**        | **136**                             |

It will be noted from the above summary that over 60% of the children of school age in Williams Lake Agency have no hope of getting an education. The Alexis Creek Band with 36 children of school age has not got a single child attending school and the Abraham Band, with a school population of 78, has 18 or 23% of the children of school age attending the Residential School. It would appear that no increase in pupilage accommodation has been provided for the past 40 years in this Agency.

In the Agent's opinion, this is a serious situation and one that will no doubt be sure to find expression in public sooner or later. Moreover, Indians are being called up for Military Training in the same manner as Whites and it must be very difficult for them, without even the rudiment of an education, to fit in to army life in this day and age. There is no doubt that they feel this handicap very keenly as I have been told on numerous occasions. It must also be borne in mind that, when this war ends, it is going to be extremely difficult for an Indian to get work and he will require to be better equipped for life than ever before.

In the present emergency it is no doubt difficult to get the material for building schools without taking into consideration the expense, but it is felt that some effort should be made to make a beginning at least in the establishment of Day Schools in the...
Reserves with a large and more compact population. In these circumstances, I would respectfully suggest that some consideration is given to the establishment of Day Schools on the Alexis Creek Indian Reserve on Redstone Meadows, and also on the Anaham Indian Reserve. Since the Alexis Creek Band have no contacts, at present at least, with the Cariboo Residential School, and since there has been some previous correspondence regarding the establishment of a Day School on this Reserve, it might be well to discuss the possibilities for such a project first.

The population of the Alexis Creek Band at present is 170. They live within a radius of two or four miles from Chief Charleyboy's land, on which the Church is built and a number of log cabins, which the Indians use during the periodic visits of the Missionary Priest. This Redstone Reserve is situated approximately 25 miles from the main highway running from Williams Lake to Kleena Kleene, 145 miles West of Williams Lake.

An item of $1,800.00 has been placed in the Estimates for construction of a log school house but in view of the difficulty experienced at present in securing an appropriation for any new buildings, I would suggest that the Church, a log building 24' x 30' is used for this purpose temporarily. Father Hennessey, the visiting Missionary, and the Indians have unanimously agreed that the Department have the use of the Church as a School building and the Priest House as a residence for the teacher. The Church is a well constructed log building with plenty of light and a suitable wood stove for heating purposes. The following material, however, will be required for interior furnishings:

School Building

- 1,000' dressed lumber for seats, desks, cupboards, from Duke Martin, Alexis Creek, B. C. $25.00
- 500' rough lumber for two outside toilets @ $20. Per M 10.00
- Nails 8.00
- Blackboards 30.00
- Freight on lumber to Redstone Meadows 30.00
- Labour constructing seats, desks, and building toilets 75.00

Total $168.00

Teachersage

- Bed, Spring and Mattress 35.00
- Cooking utensils, wash basin, brooms, etc. 30.00
- Kerosene lamp 8.00
- Camp stove and drum oven 15.00

Total $78.00

The greatest difficulty at the present time will no doubt be experienced in finding a suitable teacher. The ideal solution, since these Indians are all Roman Catholics, and it will therefore be left to the Roman Catholic Church to nominate teachers, would be to have two Sisters, one of whom had training as a Nurse and could do social work, similar to that done by district nurses in white settlements and outlying districts. The alternative would be to hire a woman without children, the wife to have had some experience or ability in social work and nursing. Since, however, the Priest's house on the Reserve is a one-roomed building, either of the latter suggestions would not be possible without an addition to the Priest's house to provide the necessary accommodation. It might be found advisable for the present to concentrate on a male teacher who is prepared to put
up without any of the modern conveniences.

The duration of the school year on this Reserve should be for nine months, October to June, inclusive.

ANAHAM BAND

The Anaham Band with a population of 302 is the largest Band in this Agency. The Reserve on which their village is built contains some of the finest cultivated land in the Chilcotin, all in one block. The Anaham Indian village is situated on the main highway, 70 miles West of Williams Lake, and is supplied with a domestic water system. Should a school be established here, it is quite possible that a number of children from the Stone Reserve, 12 miles distant, might be able to make arrangements to attend.

The Church and Priest House on this Reserve are also available for school purposes, but the Community Hall, a log building 22' x 40', would be more satisfactory. This building will require the following material to make it comfortable, and the Indians have promised to contribute the labour:

School Building

- 2,000' shiplap for floor and ceiling $50.00
- 1,500' shiplap to line walls inside $37.50
- 6 rolls of Kraft sheathing paper for floors and walls @ $1.50 each $9.00
- 2,000' dressed lumber for seats, desks, cupboards, etc. $25.00
- Nails $0.00
- Blackboard material $0.00
- 1 large heating stove $0.00
- Freight $0.00
- Labour Free $0.00

Total $31.50

Teachersage (for two teachers)

- 2 beds, springs, and mattresses $50.00
- Cooking utensils, wash basin, broom, etc. $40.00
- 1 gasoline lamp & 2 coal oil lamps $12.00
- Cook Stove $5.00
- Heater $5.00

Total $102.00

The Priest's house on the Anaham Reserve is quite a good building with three small rooms, two of which can be used as bedrooms and the other as a living-room - kitchen. The accommodation, of course, is not all that could be desired since two teachers are required on this Reserve but it would suffice for the present.

The population of this village is not much short of that in Kitimat in the Bella Coola Agency and there is a better prospect of a much larger average attendance since there is no fishing season, and, therefore, no general exodus of the people for a large part of the year.

With 75 children of school age, two teachers are the minimum requirements here as there is no doubt that some now attending the Cariboo Indian Residential School will wish to return home, thus providing accommodation for children from other reserves where a Day School is not possible.
I consider that the operation of a nine month school at the Anaham Reserve has a good chance of success and that the school year should be from October to June, inclusive.

Enclosed is a list of the children of school age & pre-school age from the Alexis Creek and Anaham Bands.

I have to refer to your letter of July 15th, 1941, and previous correspondence relating to the provision of an Indian Day School for the Alexis Creek Indians.

During a brief visit to the Alexis Creek and Anaham Reserves, the need of day schools in these Reserves was stressed by the Indians and, from the information given me at the time it was abundantly clear that something should be done as soon as possible to meet the situation. Following our meetings with the Bands mentioned I instructed Mr. Christie to secure the necessary information on the subject and let me have a report. This report has now been received and a copy is enclosed herewith.

It will be observed that there are, at present, 36 children of school age belonging to the Alexis Creek Band and 60 of the Anaham Band not attending any school. There is no accommodation for these children at any of the Catholic Residential schools, as nearly all of these schools are now carrying a few pupils in excess of the grant earning number.

I advised Mr. Christie that in view of the fact that half of the school year was nearly over and, the difficulty in securing qualified teachers, that it was unlikely that we could do more than have certain repairs made to existing suitable buildings that might be used for school purposes and, secure the necessary equipment preparatory to opening the schools in June next. Mr. Christie estimates the amount required to put the buildings in proper shape and secure certain equipment and furnishings at $629.50, but I doubt if this is sufficient and, would recommend that favourable consideration be given to authorizing an expenditure up to $1000.00 for these purposes. Principal of the Cariboo Indian School and also the Provincial of the Oblates and despite the fact that he may not have the required teaching certificate, I feel sure that he will fill the position very well, for the present, and I recommend that he is paid the salary allotted.

REPORT ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1944.

Education;

Alexis Creek Indian Day School was visited, when twenty miles had to be negotiated in low gear owing to the heavy snowfall. The general spirit of the teacher and pupils was found to be excellent, and I consider good progress has been made in the short time this school has been open. The pupils were quite responsive, and most of them could do additions up to nine. Flash cards were being used and there was a good competitive spirit between the boys and girls. Some of the children read out loud quite well, but most of them were rather shy when reading alone. Numerous drawings in crayon have been done, all of them of familiar subjects, such as horses, moose, coyotes, cowboys, etc. Some of the older girls around twenty years of age were left in charge of the younger children while their parents went on their traplines, and these girls also attend school.

I would suggest that hot cocoa and some of the pilot bread taken over from the military authorities be supplied next winter for the children's mid-day meal.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH DECEMBER, 1943.

Education:

The Cariboo Indian Residential School was more or less back to normal by the Christmas holidays. Father Hennessy stayed at Alexis Creek Indian Day School over Christmas and put on a Christmas Tree for the children, the first they have know. He reports 28 children on the roll now, and most of them very enthusiastic.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON WILLIAMS LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH NOVEMBER, 1943.

Education;

A visit was paid to the Redstone Reserve for the opening of the new Indian School with Father Hennessy in charge. Father Hennessy reports that there about 20 children in school now and that they are very enthusiastic. In fact, he states that it is the first time he has ever seen children running to school when the bell rings, mornings and afternoons.

Academic Studies have, of course, been seriously interfered with at the Cariboo Indian Residential School during the present epidemic.

EDUCATION:

The Caribou Indian Residential School opened on September 1st and the Anaham Indian Day School on September 4th, 1945. The return of the pupils to the Residential School was much better this year. It was expected that there would have been very poor attendance at the Anaham Indian Day School during September due to the fact that most of the Indians were still having away from the main Reserve, but a special effort was made to get their children back in time and practically all the pupils who attended last year are now back.

There are now fourteen pupils in the senior room and they show a very keen competitive spirit. Sr. Mary of the Angels, teacher of the senior room, visited St. Mary's school at Mission last year and saw the Pro-rec. work, and now has her pupils started on this type of physical education.

During the Indian Commissioner's visit, a site was chosen for a new school on this Reserve, and, as soon as it is possible to get a representative meeting, the Indians will be asked to surrender this land to the Department for school purposes.

January 17, 1949

Air Mail

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Redstone Indian Day School

The above mentioned school will be ready for use on January 17th. Unfortunately we have no teacher to take over at that time but the Reverend Father Fleury has kindly consented to teach until such time as we are able to find a replacement.

Application and other forms have been forwarded to Father Fleury and these will be sent to the Department as soon as they have been completed and returned.

for W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
25th January, 1949.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

We have your letter of the 17th instant in which you advise that Rev. F. Fleury is prepared to teach the Alexis Creek Day School until such time as we are able to find a replacement. It is also noted that the necessary application and other forms have been forwarded to Father Fleury for completion.

In recent letters from this office and from your office, this school has been referred to as "Redstone Indian Day School". When this school was originally started, it was understood that the name of it would be "Alexis Creek Indian Day School", and this was the name used in Order-in-Council P.C. 89 dated 7th January, 1943, which established the school.

On all future correspondence it would be appreciated if you would always refer to this school as "Alexis Creek Indian Day School".

A copy of this letter is being forwarded to Indian Superintendent Wm. Christie.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Alexis Creek Indian Day School
Your file 872-1 (E.1)

I have to refer to Mr. Neary's letter of Jan. 25th and in particular the request that in all future correspondence the above-mentioned school, situated on Charley Boy's Meadow Indian Reserve No. 3, Redstone Meadows, be referred to as "Alexis Creek Indian Day School" which was the name used in Order in Council P.C. 89 dated January 7th, 1943. This matter has been the subject of previous correspondence with the Department, reference Major MacKay's letter of September 15th, 1945, and Mr. Phelan's reply of October 30th, 1945 (file 160-22-1), wherein the Department approved use of the name Redstone Meadows Indian Day School for this particular school.

I would suggest that if the question of the proper name of this school is to crop up periodically because of the designation in the original Order in Council, that the Order in Council be changed to officially designate the school as Redstone Meadows Indian Day School. May I please be advised if we are to continue to refer to this school as Redstone Meadows as authorized in Mr. Phelan's letter referred to or if we are to revert to the name Alexis Creek Indian Day School.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
21st February, 1949.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

In view of the contents of your letter of 14th February, 1949, you may continue to use the name Redstone Meadows, but for the next few months at least, you should put the words "Alexis Creek" in brackets after the name Redstone Meadows.

PP/ST

Bernard H. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

In order to facilitate filing, it would be appreciated if, in future correspondence, you would refer to this school by the official name.

R.A. Hoey,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Education:

Alexis Creek Indian Day School was visited, when twenty miles had to be negotiated in low gear owing to the heavy snowfall. The general spirit of the teacher and pupils was found to be excellent, and I consider good progress has been made in the short time this school has been open. The pupils were quite responsive, and most of them could do additions up to nine. Flash cards were being used and there was a good competitive spirit between the boys and girls. Some of the children read out loud quite well, but most of them were rather shy when reading alone. Numerous drawings in crayon have been done, all of them of familiar subjects, such as horses, moose, coyotes, cowboys, etc. Some of the older girls around twenty years of age were left in charge of the younger children while their parents went on their traplines, and these girls also attend school.

I would suggest that hot cocoa and some of the pilot bread taken over from the military authorities be supplied next winter for the children's mid-day meal.

Wm. Christie,

EDUCATION

Day School on Redstone Meadows Reserve closed at the end of March as Father Hennessy has to resume his Missionary work on the other Reserves. Good progress is being made here considering school is open for only five months and the Agent was particularly impressed with the drawings done by these children who took part in the Tuberculosis poster competition and also in the one sponsored by the Department of National Health and Welfare on foods. It was noted that the water supply on this reserve and school is bad, especially in the spring when the spring run-off from the surrounding horse and cattle corrals must pollute the drinking water. The Indians were asked to dig two wells for the village and another for the school and no doubt the Department will agree to provide the necessary lumber for lumber for cribbing and perhaps two pumps so that the well can be closed in.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 22 June 1948.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated June 9th, 1948, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence at Redstone, on the Alexis Creek Indian Reserve, in the Williams Lake Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Alexis Creek Indian Reserve;

That Section 36 of The Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest . . . . . .";

That, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

That a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 469, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated school with attached teacher's residence immediately on a basis of $5,850.00 f.o.b. Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses;

That it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the provision of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Re: New School - Redstone

Attached is a tender on the basement for new school at Redstone Meadows from Mr. George Taylor and Mr. Vogelaar of Williams Lake.

These contractors have not had any experience with pre-fabricated buildings and for that reason did not wish to contract for erection of the building.

I suggested that the concrete part of the basement only come to one foot above ground level as this would save on cement and freight which costs £25.00 per ton from Williams Lake. Moreover it will make a more comfortable basement which can be used as a Community Centre and manual training room.

The price seems quite high but freight is a large item and it is difficult to get a contractor to go out to these isolated locations.

The wages mentioned are presumably the union rates but you could check on this at Vancouver.

Messrs Taylor and Vogelaar, one of whom will be going out as foreman carpenter are good workers and are at present building an addition to the Bank of Montreal here.

Should this tender and arrangements be considered satisfactory I will take these men out to mark out the foundation for excavation at once.

Wm. Christie,

W. S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver, B. C.

In explanation of the attached Voucher which should have had the Department's authorization, I would submit the following information.

There is 22 miles of road into Redstone Meadows Indian Day School which has been entirely constructed by the Indians with a little assistance from the Department in 1942 amounting to about $200.00 for food. Since all the work was done with horses and hand labour it was only possible to do a minimum of work and since there are no white settlers living on this road, no assistance was provided by the Provincial Government.

The excessive rains this summer added to the difficulties of transporting materials for the construction of the new school and the first two truckloads got mired, one of them breaking an axle about six miles from their destination in crossing the edge of a meadow and the freight including 350 sacks of cement had to be unloaded.

Something had to be done in a hurry and I contacted Mr. Knoll who was busy haying. He very kindly took his bulldozer about twelve miles across country and bulldozed a road around this meadow, also fixing up some other bad holes near the school.

He spent 20 hours travelling back and forward and half of this time was charged to Taylor & Vogelaar for whom he also excavated the basement of the school.

This account should be charged to improvement to roads and I trust will meet with your approval.

Wm. Christie,
Supt., Wms. Lake Indian Agency.

December 9, 1948.

W. S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

Referring to voucher number 684 for 350 pounds of pudio for the Day School at Redstone Meadows I have to advise that this was purchased to mix with the cement for the foundation of the Prefabricated School at Redstone Meadows.

I thought that it was advisable to use this water repellent in the cement, in view of the fact that the water level is three feet below the surface.

The contractor of course, was not aware of this when he submitted his tender and there was no time to get authority from the Department.

Wm. Christie,
Supt., Wms. Lake Indian Agency.

February 10th, 1949.

W.S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C., VANCOUVER, B.C.

Re: Alexis Creek Indian Day School - Redstone Meadows

Enclosed herewith is credit voucher # 99 for wages paid in connection with the construction of the new school at Redstone Meadows.

I regret the delay in forwarding this Voucher and I might add that I am recently in receipt of a letter from Superintendent of Education, Mr Neary in this connection.

As you may recall this school was practically completed by November 27th but unfortunately the workmen ran short of siding. When the siding came I made up a load with school desks, shiplap for toilets and two tons of grain for the Indians, trucking of the latter to be paid from the appropriation for that purpose.

I had also arranged to take Mr Taylor in the same day to finish the school and set up the desks but he excused himself at the last moment. Subsequently I had to get his partner to go in Mr Vogelaar and I had him set up the desks on 1" x 4", all the school-room floor and finish the siding. It appears however that Mr Taylor did not estimate correctly the amount of siding that was short and about 160f.b.m. is still required. I do not propose to hire a carpenter for the balance of this work however which can be done in a short time with Indian help.

Completion of the heating system by Mr Schwab of Mitchell Brothers is still awaited but this should not take very long. With the recent heavy snowfall and drifted roads it may be difficult to get into Redstone Meadows for a few weeks in view of the fact that there is 22 miles of this road which is not snow-plowed.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, OTTAWA

In reply to your letter of the 2nd instant, regarding expenditures for wages in connection with the construction of the new day School at Redstone Meadows, a credit Vr. #99 has been forwarded to the Indian Commissioner with pay lists amounting to $1364.53.

I received two advances amounting in all to $2100.00 and I have now submitted credit vouchers amounting to $1930.09 which leaves a balance unexpended amounting to $169.91.

Some difficulty has been experienced in getting this school completed although it was practically finished in November. Unfortunately however there was a shortage of material in connection with the heating system and also in the material supplied by Pre-fabricated Buildings Ltd.

I am still awaiting completion of the heating system which is being done by Mitchell Brothers man at present working on the Anaham Indian Day School. The recent heavy snowfall may further delay this work as it is difficult to get into the meadows now with a motor vehicle and tradesmen do not appreciate travelling by sleigh any more.

However, I put on a National Film Board show in the new school at Redstone Meadows on Xmas week and found the temporary heating arrangements quite comfortable, and I can assure the Department that they have got a very good and suitable building.

Wm. Christie,
Indian Superintendent.
