PRECIS FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL.

Requesting authority for the provision of a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence at Redstone, on the Alexis Creek Indian Reserve, in the Williams Lake Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, for which funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates.

Two extra copies of Order-in-Council are required.
June 9, 1948.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence at Redstone, on the Alexis Creek Indian Reserve, in the Williams Lake Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Alexis Creek Indian Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ..........";

THAT, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 459, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated school with attached teacher's residence immediately on a basis of $5,850.00 f.o.b. Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses.

THAT it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency on within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the provision of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Respectfully submitted,

Acting Minister of Mines and Resources.

December 2nd, 1944.

Mr. Gillett, Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C.

Your File 12-11-1A

I have to refer to your letter of November 7th enclosing a copy of your letter to Nelson Brothers regarding the need of providing educational facilities for the Indian children in residence at Port Edward and a place called Billmor. You will recall that this matter was briefly discussed with you when you visited this office some weeks ago.

Following representations dating back to August last, Mr. R. Nelson of Nelson Brothers, visited this office on Wednesday when this subject was reviewed. I assured Mr. Nelson that I felt the Department would not hesitate to provide the necessary equipment and authorize the appointment of a teacher once suitable accommodation could be secured. Mr. Nelson advised that a suitable building was not available at the present time but that the Company had under consideration plans which if carried out would make available early in the New Year a building that could be used for school purposes until better arrangements could be made. He promised to advise me more definitely in this connection at an early date and when this information is received here you will be further advised. In the meantime the Department is being asked to authorize the employment of a teacher and the purchase of blackboards and other equipment so that necessary action may be taken once we are assured that a suitable building will be made available.

When Inspector Thorsteinsson was here he intimated that he might be able to assist us in securing a qualified teacher to operate the school. Please discuss this point with him and let me have the necessary particulars in order that the matter may be referred to the Department. As the Indians concerned belong to various Protestant bodies I should say that the Department would be in a position to make an appointment without the necessity of securing the usual Church nomination.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
PRINCE RUPERT, B.C.,
December 1, 1944.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., VANCOUVER, B.C.

Have just returned from Fort Edward, after conferring with Mr. Robbins, Manager of Nelson Brothers' Cannery relative to school facilities for Indian children at that place. I gathered that the Commissioner had discussed the matter with Mr. Richard Nelson.

Mr. Robbins will make it feasible for the Chinese dining-room to be converted into a room for school purposes. It is forty feet long and twelve feet wide, with a good heater, electric light, and four flush toilets, for which partitions will be erected so that two will be in each room. The Company will provide the coal and light.

If it is the intention of the Department to provide a teacher, this building would be available the first of January. Not less than forty desks will be required. The desks should be ten large, twenty medium, and ten small. Approximately thirty lineal feet of blackboard will be required.

The building mentioned above will be used up to April 1st, after which date a building now used by the white people as a dining-room will be available, unless we can secure one of the American buildings near the cannery site.

I hope to be in Vancouver on the 15th, and will explain the building situation then.

J.G./k.

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

For some time the question of providing educational facilities for the children of Indians employed at the Fort Edward Cannery has been under consideration with Nelson Brothers who own and operate the plant. The matter has progressed to the stage where the Company has accepted responsibility for providing the necessary classroom accommodation which will be in readiness by January 1st. There are at present thirty Indian children of school age available to attend with a possibility of twenty more after the new year.

It is considered that advantage should be taken of the offer made by the Company and in order to avoid undue delay in getting the school started I should appreciate authority to purchase the necessary desks, blackboards, teacher's desk and chair and other items of equipment necessary in a classroom. There are at the moment ten or twelve complete desks surplus to requirements at the Pemberton Indian Day School and it is my intention to send these to Fort Edward unless the Department instructs otherwise.

It is doubtful if a nomination is necessary in this case as the Indians employed at Fort Edward belong to various religious denominations and I would, therefore, suggest that an appointment be made without reference to the Church once the services of a properly qualified teacher can be secured.

Copies of correspondence in connection with this matter are enclosed for your information.

D.M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
December 18, 1944.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are thirty (30) Indian children of school age residing near the Port Edward Cannery, Skeena Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, for whom at present no educational facilities are provided;

THAT funds are available in Vote 165, 1944-45, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for the establishment of a day school at Port Edward.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that a day school be established at Port Edward, Skeena Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, in accordance with the provisions of Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, Chapter 92, 1887, to be known as "The Port Edward Indian Day School".

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

December 15, 1944.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to providing educational facilities for the children of Indians employed at the Port Edward Cannery. It is noted that Nelson Brothers are prepared to provide a building for classroom purposes. You do not mention any living quarters for the teacher, but presumably these are available.

In order to permit our paying salary for a teacher at this point it will be necessary for us to establish the school as required under Section 9A of the Indian Act. We have made application for the necessary Order-in-Council and I am hopeful that this will be passed in the near future. Until this is done we cannot definitely approve the opening of the school. However, in the meantime I should appreciate your making inquiries with a view to securing a qualified teacher to take charge of the school and I would also like you to let me know what salary you consider we should allow in the event of the school being opened.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, December 12, 1944.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

Indian Commissioner MacKay has brought to our attention the necessity of providing educational facilities for the children of Indians employed at the Port Edward Cannery, Skeena Agency, British Columbia. This cannery is operated by Nelson Brothers, who are prepared to provide a building for classroom purposes. This building is stated to be 40 ft. long, 12 ft. wide, heated, lighted by electricity and with four flush toilets available. The Company is prepared to supply this building and heat it free of cost.

We would have to supply a few desks, blackboards and other small items of classroom equipment as well as pay the salary of the teacher.

Indian Commissioner MacKay and Agent Gillett strongly recommend that the offer be accepted and that the school be placed in operation on January 1, 1945. In order to permit us to do so, an Order-in-Council will be necessary, establishing the school, as required under Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act. I enclose Memorandum to Council, which, I hope, meets with your approval.

Acting Director.

With reference to your letter of Oct. 2nd, requesting more details as to pupilage etc. for the Fort Edward school, I wish to advise that there are 61 children their from the following Bands:

- Kincolith - 9
- Fort Simpson - 8
- Nassett - 13
- Skidegate - 1

The parents of these children state that they will be remaining there from now until the next salmon season. There will be a large increase in pupils during the herring season which is usually from December to March. It is not likely that the canning of herring will continue after this year if the food supply in Europe improves. However, according to information given by the management of the cannery, there will be at least 20 children there continually even if the herring cannery does not operate and during March each year, cannery workers are taken on for repair work; this will mean an increase in pupilage. I might point out that the B.C. Packers have a reduction plant at Fort Edward and some of the Indians are employed by them. This plant will continue to operate even if the canning of herring is discontinued in 1947.

My opinion is that a school will always be needed at Port Edward as long as the salmon industry continues.

At present nothing can be done towards securing a lease on the land on which the building stands because the final transfer through the War Assets Board has not yet been completed. It is the intention of the Nelson Brothers Cannery to apply for a lease of land which would include the
school site. It appears there is no doubt that the cannery people will take the land as soon as it can be arranged. They in turn will lease Lot #10 to our department at a very nominal rate, so that we will have complete control of the building and the lot.

In the meantime I would recommend that we use the same building we used last year, namely the Chinese workers dining room. This is available now and before the salmon season opens next year it is possible that the building and lot now belonging to the U.S. Army, could be transferred to our department.

In a previous letter we recommended Miss Olive Wishart as teacher for the Port Edward school. She is still available and I consider her quite capable of handling the school.

I would appreciate an early reply so that we can open the school with the 31 children now there.

EXTRACT FROM QUARTERLY REPORT ON SKEENA RIVER AGENCY SUBMITTED BY MR. INDIAN SUPERINTENDENT ANFIELD DATED APRIL 11, 1949

"Negotiations are in hand to have Indian pupils educated at Port Edward. If successful, it will be possible to close our Indian Day School at the cannery. Similar action is suggested for the Sunnyside Cannery school in the year 1950."

(Original on file 75-168)

28-4-49.
I have had considerable discussion with the School Board Representative at Port Edward and also with the Prince Rupert District School Board. As a result of the last meeting, the Board have agreed in principle that they will have to accept responsibility for the education of Indians in the Port Edward Area. It is, therefore, recommended that the Department give immediate consideration to closing the Port Edward Indian Day School as from June 30th, this year.

In reply to a direct question, I informed the School Board that I would be prepared to recommend that the present equipment at the Day School and teacherge at Port Edward be rented to the Prince Rupert School Board for a nominal sum. It is likely that the number of Indians attending this School will be 75% of the enrollment. As the Indians situated in the Port Edward area do not pay rent, it is presumed that the Department may consent to the payment of per capita costs of education in the white school district.

Your further advice and instructions regarding the recommendation contained herein will be appreciated.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Re: Port Edward Indian Day School

Attached is a copy of a letter from Mr. Superintendent Anfield recommending the closing of the above-mentioned school. It will be recalled that this school is located on cannery property within the Prince Rupert School District. It is doubtful if the Department should continue the operation of an Indian school within the confines of a provincial School District.

This matter was discussed by Inspector Davey with Mr. Anfield and later with the Port Edward Representative on the School Board. I am in agreement with Mr. Anfield and Inspector Davey that the Department should close the Port Edward School, providing the School District is prepared to admit our children on the basis outlined in Mr. Anfield's letter.

I shall appreciate receiving the Department's instructions as to whether I should proceed with negotiations with the School Board.

W.S. Arneil
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

PORT EDWARD Indian Day School, B. C.

You are well aware of local conditions involved in the operation of this school. I understand that for some time negotiations have been proceeding for the closing of this school as was done at Port Essington. You will find hereunder an outline of the negotiations as they have proceeded to date.

In view of the success of the Port Essington experiment, I would recommend that the Prince Rupert School District be approached concerning an agreement for the education of these Indian children. If satisfactory arrangements can be completed, then I would recommend that the Port Edward Indian Day School be closed.

As you are aware, we have never been able to obtain the services of particularly satisfactory teachers at this school and it was only in September of this academic year that our School Inspector was able to obtain qualified teachers. We will naturally be able to use the services of these teachers in other day schools in British Columbia, if so recommended by Mr. Arneil.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Ottawa, February 22, 1945.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Box 70, Vancouver, B. C.

I have your letter of the 19th instant, regarding the transfer of Captain E. L. Bailey from Kitselas to the Port Edward Indian Day School. It is noted that she took charge of the Port Edward School on February 12. Salary will be allowed her from that date at the rate of $105.00 a teaching month.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, June 8, 1945.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY.

Re: Port Edward Indian Day School,
No. 673.

Please note that the teacher of this school, Captain E. L. Bailey, gave up duties on June 1, 1945, and no further payment of salary should be made to her after that date.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, November 12, 1945.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY.

Re: Port Edward Indian Day School,
No. 873.

I wish to refer you to memorandum of June 8, 1945, in which you were informed that Captain E.L. Bailey had given up duties at the above-named school on June 1, 1945.

To succeed her the Department has approved the appointment of Miss Olive Wishart as teacher, at a salary of $105.00 a teaching month plus bonus, effective October 16, 1945.

I attach T.D.I form and cost-of-living bonus form. Questionnaire has already been submitted to you. Copy of letter of appointment is attached.

For Deputy Minister.

Encl.
Ottawa, 16 September 1946.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Fort Edward Indian Day School - No. 873

Mrs. Lucy F. Wishart has been appointed teacher of this school at a salary of $131.00 a teaching month effective Sept. 1st, 1946. I enclose copy of letter of appointment, also T.D. 1 Form and Copy of Living Bonus Form. The staff questionnaire will reach you shortly.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, June 21, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, British Columbia.

With reference to your letter of the 14th instant, the Department approves the appointment of Mrs. Lucy E. Wishart as teacher of the senior room at the Port Edward Indian Day School for the academic year 1946-47.

Salary will be allowed her at the rate of $105.00 per teaching month, plus bonus. As soon as she begins duties you should have her complete and return the usual forms. These should reach us not later than September 10, in order to ensure Mrs. Wishart's name being included on the September pay-list.

For Deputy Minister.

Re: Building for School at Port Edward

The Commissioner's office has requested that I air-mail information with reference to a building at Port Edward belonging to the U.S. Army which may be secured for school purposes. The locality, dimensions and improvements required are as follows:

1. The accompanying sketch will show the relation of the building to the cannery property and the Indian homes. The land on which the building stands belongs to the provincial government.

2. The building is 80 ft. long and 30 ft. wide with 9 ft. walls, peak roof, wood construction, outside walls shiplap and heavy tarred paper with battens covering the seams. The roof is shiplap with heavy wartime roofing. It has double flooring, double doors in end and one on the side. There is a suitable playground in front 100' x 60'.

3. Improvements: The building needs lining, and I would suggest that 40 ft. be partitioned off for the school room. The following material will be required:

- 2,800 sq. ft. of Domacona @ $60.00 per M = $168.00
- 1,000 ft. Shiplap @ $59.00 per M = $59.00
- 1,000 ft. 2" x 4" @ $59.00 per M = $59.00
- 20 lb. assorted nails @ .12¢ = $2.40

Total ........... $288.90
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I have to refer to Mr. Indian Agent Gillett's air mail letter of September 22nd to the Department, a copy of which has been received at this office, in connection with the proposed acquisition of a U.S. Army building at Port Edward for use as a schoolroom.

It is not considered that Mr. Gillett has given us sufficient details in this matter, particularly the basis under which the building could be used for school purposes. It would appear that we should be assured of tenure of the building for a reasonable length of time before undertaking improvements amounting to $450.00 and I am, therefore, writing to Mr. Gillett asking that he take the matter up with the United States Army authorities in Prince Rupert and that he ascertain under what arrangements the land on which the building stands is in use by the U.S. Army. I am also asking Mr. Gillett to supply further information with respect to the available pupilage, and the possibility of maintaining a fair attendance at the school for a reasonable length of time. It is recommended that no action be taken pending receipt of this information from Mr. Gillett.

D.M. MacKay,

Major R. W. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Fort Edward School - Prince Rupert Agency

An inspection of the above named Indian Day School (seasonal) was made with Indian Agent Gillett on April 3rd. There were twenty-three pupils present in grades from two and up. In the forenoon there had been an attendance of twenty-nine primary children. Some represented included Fort Simpson, Kitimat, Greenville and Fort Nelson of Massicotte Agency, Bennett of Upper Charlotte Agency, and Kitimat of the Bella Coola Agency. Miss O. Plummer, the teacher at this school and bearing in mind her lack of training, is making a very fair effort. Health of the pupils appeared satisfactory, though cases of scabies were noticed. An age grade survey was made and the class visited had a grade age retardation score of about 2.5 years.

The physical plant of this temporary school is poor, the Cannery Manager, Mr. Robbings, has informed the Agent that he will require the building shortly for quarters as a Chinese bunk house. Some twelve Chinese have already occupied one end of the building.

Mr. Robbings has now taken over by purchase from the Cariboo Corporation and Dept. of Veterans Affairs a building 100 ft. x 80 ft. and most suitable for a two room school, and five room teacherage. Nelson Bros., Ltd., operators of this cannery, are securing the site of these buildings from the Province. Site and building are immediately adjacent to Nelson Bros. property at Fort Edwards and easily accessible from the Indian houses.

This building was inspected carefully and is considered suitable for conversion into a two room school and teacherage adjacent. It has fair playground space and is safely removed from the railroad tracks. Elevation, lighting and drainage all are satisfactory. Other conditions were discussed with Mr. Robbings who is anxious to cooperate in the maintenance of this school. The following plan was conceived and is placed before the Department for immediate consideration, it being urgent that the present premises be vacated and the school carried on with facilities of location as possible.

Nelson Bros., Ltd., by the Manager, agree to:

(a) Convert the building herein mentioned to a two room school and a five room teacherage, in accordance with standard school practice and to follow, as far as material and labour will permit, a sketch plan to be submitted by the Agent.

(b) Provide electric light, water and sewerage, but not fuel, which will however be made available by the company and charged to the Dept.

(c) Maintain and repair said building as a school, and in the year 1947 put thereon a shingle roof at the expense of the company.

(d) Move at company expense the equipment and material now used in the present school and install same in the new school building.

(e) Utilize in said building the linings, partitions, toilets, wash basins and heaters to be salvaged from the Dundas Pt. barracks building (naval barracks turned over to the Department) and to make available snow and boat for moving said material to Fort Edwards when available.

(over)

Indian Affairs. (RC 10, Volume 6425, file 873-5, part 1)
The Department by the Agent, to pay a monthly rent of $25.00 for said building completed and occupied as a school from date of occupancy, and in addition will:

(a) Take down and salvage a 70 ft. x 18 ft. building at Sundan Pt., load on a scow and unload scow at Fort Edwards all usable material including especially wall board, lumber, toilets, heaters and plumbing, electrical fixtures and make same available to Nelson Bros. for incorporation in the projected school building at Fort Edwards. Estimated value of this material: $1100.00 all of which has been given free to the Department by War Assets Committee.

(b) To pay for dismantling this building at Sundan Pt., for loading onto scow and unloading same at Fort Edwards wharf; for which purpose it is estimated a sum of $350.00 will be required. If granted, an accountable advance for this sum to be paid into the Nanaimo Indian Agency Trust Account immediately so wages can be met.

(c) The Department to supply school equipment required, including desks, blackboards and school supplies, same to revert to the Dept. if school is closed.

(d) The Department to pay for fuel and teachers salaries.

(e) The Department to provide two teachers at opening of new term in September.

If this plan is carried through there will be available a most suitable two room school and teacherage at a straight rental. If economic conditions change so that the school need not be maintained, the Department will only be out the $350.00 spent on wages dismantling the building at Sundan Pt., the material in which cost the department nothing. The chief reason for moving this material is shortage of same and inability of the agency to purchase in the open market. In any case, the cost is only that of wages, estimated at $350.00 and it will cost much more than this for the company to shingle the building next year.

In view of all these considerations, it is considered much better for the Department to rent them to try and acquire by purchase and later maintain a building of its own at this plant.

It is recommended that the plan as outlined be accepted as soon as possible; that the agent be notified of approval or otherwise at Prince Rupert; and that if approved, an accountable cheque for $350.00 be forwarded forthwith by airmail.

April 23rd, 1946.

F. E. Anfield, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C.

I have your letter of April 6th in connection with the Port Edward Indian Day School building.

In reviewing our file it is noted that the original proposal in connection with this building was that the Department acquire it and equip it for school purposes. This proposal was subsequently amended in that Nelson Brothers would acquire the building and lease it to us for a nominal amount as they apparently were interested in acquiring the land on which the building was situated. It now appears that Nelson Brothers have acquired the building and it is proposed that the people of Canada give them materials valued at $1100 and labour to the extent of $250.00 and in addition pay them $25.00 a month rent which proposal in my opinion could not be considered particularly in view of the fact that there will be nothing to prevent Nelson Brothers forcing us to vacate the building should they require it for their own purposes or in the event the Cannery was closed in which case we would have no claims on the $1350.00 invested.

I may say that in 1944 I had an opportunity of discussing this matter with the Manager of Nelson Brothers and at that time the Company intimated that they would be prepared to provide us with a building without cost if we would equip it and operate it as a school for Indian children. It is a considerable departure to the proposal now before us. I would suggest that you discuss the matter further with the Manager of Nelson Brothers at the earliest opportunity and endeavour to obtain a more reasonable proposal from them.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Your File 168-38-5

I have your letter of April 26th and note that you have received from Mr. Anfield a copy of his letter to me of April 6th regarding the Fort Edward Indian Day School.

The proposals submitted by Mr. Anfield were given attention here and a reply forwarded to him on April 23rd, a copy of which is enclosed herewith for your information.

It seemed to me most unreasonable to expect this Department to furnish material and labour to the extent suggested by Mr. Anfield and at the same time require us to pay a rental of $25.00 per month for the building without any security as to tenure. However I have just discussed the whole matter with Mr. Indian Agent Gillett who is quite familiar with the situation and Mr. Robbins, Manager of Nelson Brothers Cannery, and find that the value of the building at Dundas Point, including the equipment therein, turned over to us by the Department of Defence, is very little more than $200.00 based on the prices secured for similar Army camp buildings in the area. Under these circumstances I should say the proposal submitted by Mr. Anfield is fair and this is also Mr. Gillett's opinion.

The Company will give us whatever agreement we require with respect to tenure of the building. In this case I should say it would be sufficient if we are given a written statement to the effect that we could have the use of the building for school purposes so long as we
require it.

The rental of $25.00 a month may appear high but not when the Company is to provide electric light, water and sewerage and fully maintain these services and the building without cost to the Department.

I would therefore recommend that the Department approve of the arrangement suggested and would appreciate a decision by air mail in order that, if the plan is endorsed, the Company may proceed to carry out the alterations to the building at Port Edward to be used for an Indian Day School and teacher's residence.

November 19th, 1947

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

The Department recently gave authority to buy sugar and cocoa for school lunches at the Day Schools of this Agency. It was my plan that the children should themselves supply the canned milk for these hot drinks on a rotational basis, each child bringing one or two cans once a month. Most of the schools have accepted this plan and are glad to conform.

However, we have had a bad year fishing and on the Naas in particular whooping cough is prevalent in many homes. Reports from Aiyansh in particular are that there will be hardship this winter and that the children are under-nourished. Similar reports are to hand from Greenville. The teachers are willing to co-operate in these recess lunches, and authority is requested to purchase 6 cases of canned milk, Pacific tall, @ $7.50 per case from local stores in Aiyansh and Greenville to supplement what the children may bring in. The retail price in Prince Rupert is $.20 and freight and handling charges up the Naas River are $.30 per case. I can wire or radio the teachers concerned if the authority to buy is authorized.

I have discussed this with Dr. Macdonald and he states that anything that can be done to maintain health standards in these two villages in particular should be done, as the whooping cough will take quite a toll in both places. It should be stated that there will be little or no employment for the natives resident in either of these villages this winter, apart from trapping, the market for which is a very uncertain quantity at this time.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario

Your File 168-38-5 (WT 1)

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of Oct. 3rd approving an expenditure of $79.00 for the purpose of supplying a hot drink for the pupils of the various schools in the Skeena River Agency, I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letter of November 19th wherein he requests authority for an expenditure of a further amount of $45.00 for the purchase of canned milk for the reason stated. The total expenditure involved is not large and I would recommend that authority be granted for the purchase of six cases of canned milk.

D. M. MacKay
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
AIR MAIL

Ottawa, November 29th, 1947.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

In view of the recommendation contained in your letter of November 26th, file 12-11-1, we approve an expenditure of a further amount of $45.00 for the purchase of canned milk to be served to the children attending the schools in the Skeena River Agency.

Indian Agent Anfield should be informed that this is a special grant which is being given in view of the conditions outlined in his letter of November 19th which you forwarded with your communication.

In view of the payment of Family Allowances, we feel that the parents should be in a position to feed their children better than formerly and even supply them with some lunch when going to school.

With this in mind our general policy has been to only allow for mid day meal purposes, the same amount as in previous years.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

General comment:

Miss Bailey is doing her best in this situation. She does not appear to be as able to handle this school as successfully as Kiteles. The larger number of children as well as the type of pupil in the higher grades appears to have a bearing on the situation.

The low attendance recorded is due to the fact that Grades I and II meet in the afternoon, leaving only 8 pupils for the morning session. I shall visit the Grades I and II at a later date.

This school is housed in temporary quarters and conducted by a fairly weak teacher. In spite of this the establishment of this school in its present location and the selection of the teacher were the very best arrangements under the circumstances.

The four pupils in attendance are bright boys and should, with application, do very well.

B. Thorsteinsson, Inspector of Schools

I enclose herewith Provincial School Inspector Thorsteinsson's report covering his inspection of the Port Edward Indian Day School.

As you are aware this school was recently closed due to the fact that the Cannery required the building to house their employees. In the event that it is re-opened at some later date I am of the opinion that it would be well to secure the services of a stronger teacher if possible.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Under this heading give your opinion on the condition of the school in regard to management, progress, etc., and any matters of interest regarding the school. Requests for supplies, repairs to buildings, etc., should be the subject of separate communications.

Miss Wishart has three groups within Grade I. Of the 31 children present, 7 were 6 yrs of age; 4 were 7 yrs. of age; 8 were 8 yrs. of age; 8 were 9 yrs. of age; 3 were 10 yrs. of age and 1 was 11 yrs. of age. This gives a grade average of 7.6 yrs. for this group.

Distribution by Agencies: Skeena River - 17; Queen Charlotte Is. - 10; Babine - 4.

The teacher (untrained) has made considerable improvement since I last visited this School. Control is fairly good, but a shortage of pencils and scribblers makes it difficult to keep the children busy. School Bulletin No. 1 was noted. The teacher had not submitted her requisition and was advised to do so at once.

In general, the work of the room is satisfactory, but more time should obviously be spent by the teacher in preparation of lessons.

There is a need of a separate exit for this room; cloakroom with hooks for clothing; and more toilet facilities. These matters will be taken up with Nelson Bros. Ltd. from whom the building is rented.

General Comment:

Greater emphasis should be given to silent reading with simple tests to ensure that the pupils have understood the passages read. The need for vocabulary building is very evident both for reading and language purposes.

The one grade 7 pupil is attempting work far too difficult for her. She should be given instruction in the basic subjects of reading, language, and arithmetic at a grade five level.

The remainder of the class is fairly well graded and seems to be making fair progress.

The pupils are not clean and though this may be partly due to the employment of the mothers in the plant, the teacher could make a considerable contribution by insisting that the pupils wash either before they come to school or when they arrive.

Discipline in the school is not as good as it should be.

R.F. Daney Inspector of Schools

I am enclosing for your information copies of Mr. H.F. Davey's reports covering his inspections of the Port Edward and Metlakatla Indian Day Schools.

With reference to the Port Edward School Mr. Davey informs me that the second teacher, Miss Olive Wishart, was sick on the occasion of his visit, and consequently there is no report on her work.

The services of Mrs. Lucy Wishart apparently are not altogether satisfactory, but possibly the Inspector's visit will have been of some help to her and it is hoped there will be some improvement before the next inspection.

Mr. Davey's comments with respect to the Metlakatla School building and teacherage are noted and no doubt will be subject of a report from Mr. Indian Agent Anfield, who included an amount of $3500.00 in his 1947-48 estimates for construction of a one roomed school with teacher's residence at this point.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver.

Application is made to purchase an oil burning range for the Port Edward Indian Day School teacherage. Attached please find a bid on a suitable range which is immediately available at Port Simpson from the Hudson's Bay Company. They have only the one range and I understand that one account of the impending oil shortage no more are to be released for sale.

The Manager at the Nelson Bros. plant has given assurance that he will supply all needed fuel oil for this stove.

The teachers at this school have struggled all last year with an old army stove which was brought over from one of the army establishments turned over to us after the war. It has given very poor service and an examination made of it recently shows that it is pretty well burned through. The ladies have been unable to use the oven at all for the past few months.

My reason for wishing to buy this teacherage an oil stove is the need for steady heat in the teacherage which is an old army hut well up off the ground. The construction is at the best of a very kind, the place is drafty and last winter these ladies suffered so much from cold that they nearly quit their jobs.

An oil heater has been installed in the living room and with the strongly recommended installation of this range in the kitchen, living conditions will be such as to induce these ladies to stay with the work. At least they will have steady heat in their home. As the Hudson's Bay Company can only hold this range for a limited time, the Department's instructions will be appreciated as soon as possible.

F. Earl Anfield
Indian Agent.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo,
in further reference to your communication of
June 2, with regard to the establishment of an
Indian day school at Sunnyside.

We are endeavouring to secure the
necessary Order-in-Council establishing this
school, and as soon as it is obtained you will
be advised.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Gillett's letter of September 8th in connection with the proposed establishment of an Indian Day School at Sunnyside. This proposal was brought to the Department's attention in June of this year, reference Mr. Phelan's letter 168-38-1 of June 8th, but it was not considered advisable to put the school in operation for the remaining few weeks of the academic year.

The situation apparently has changed somewhat, and it would appear that there may be thirty children available during the ten months of the school year in view of which it is considered that it would be advisable to establish a school at this point. The Church building referred to is 30' x 40' and would meet our requirements for a school room. The only cost to the Department would be a monthly rental of $10.00, in addition to the cost of the necessary equipment. We are having some difficulty in securing school desks at the present time but Mr. Gillett in a recent communication advised that there were a large number of suitable tables belonging to various forces in Prince Rupert which could be purchased for $3.00 each with suitable chairs at $1.00 each, and if we are unsuccessful in securing desks these tables might meet the requirements in the meantime.

It is recommended that the necessary Order-in-Council be secured for the establishment of a school at this point and that authority be granted for purchase of a heater, blackboard, chalk trough and the necessary desks.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

PRINCE RUPERT, B.C.,
April 28, 1945.

Mjr. D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., VANCOUVER

When at Sunnyside Cannery recently I found that there were thirty children of school age there from the various villages and agencies, the majority of which were from Port Simpson.

At Sunnyside there is a church building 30' x 40', the property of the United Church which at present is not in use. If this could be secured it would be suitable for a temporary school. The lighting is poor and the walls constructed of siding only; no inside lining. The lighting could be improved by cutting down the trees and the stove already in the building would be sufficient to keep the building warm enough for this time of year.

Would the department consider transferring the teacher from the junior room at Port Simpson to Sunnyside? The attendance at Port Simpson has reached the stage now where one teacher could manage the children. The average attendance for March was 30.07 and for April, up to the 27th, 31 and is gradually declining as the people move away.

Desks could be transferred from Port Simpson but we would need a blackboard, 4 pieces 4' x 8'.

There is a small building near the church which could be used for the teacher. I have spoken to Miss Ayser and she is willing to make the transfer if authorized.

If the department approves of having a temporary school at Sunnyside, may I suggest that consideration be given to the idea of having it continue until at least the end of July. In this case it might be advisable to appoint a teacher for Sunnyside and not to make a transfer from Port Simpson. Would Mrs. Kathleen Gray consider being appointed?

J. Gillett, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C.

The Reverend Wilding called here regarding the use of the United Church and dwelling as a school and teacher's quarters, and while he was perfectly agreeable to its use for this purpose, subject to services in the church out of school hours, he was unable to decide on a rental, consequently I asked him to discuss this and other details of occupation with you when he is in Prince Rupert, about May 25th.

In order that this matter may be placed before the Department I would request a detailed report showing what equipment and furnishings are required, with approximate cost if you are not able to secure local quotations. Also a survey of the Indian children at Sunnyside who would attend, their Reserves and religion. If furnishings are required for the dwelling, they should be listed. Possibly you could arrange with Mr. Anfield to take over the desks and blackboard in the old school house at Kitimaat if he has not already transferred them for the new classroom at Bella Coola.

Presuming that the children have already missed a great deal of their school work for the year it might be considered expedient to carry on the school until the end of July as suggested. You should advise if the children will be at the cannery when schools reopen in September. It will be difficult to get authorization of this project and all furnishings etc., completed by the end of the month and the Department may not feel that part of June and July, say six weeks, would justify the expense. However, on hearing from you further I will take the matter up with the Department.

For D.M. MacKay,

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are thirty (30) Indian children of school age, living in the vicinity of Sunnyside, Skeena Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, for whom educational facilities are required;

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

I am in receipt of a letter from Indian Commissioner MacKay, recommending the establishment of an Indian Day School at Sunnyside, in the Skeena Agency.

It is stated that there are thirty children of school age whose parents are working in the cannery at Sunnyside.

There is a building available, owned by the United Church, and the operators of the Cannery - The B.C. Packers, Limited - intend to put this building in good shape, without cost to the Department. They intend to clear the trees away from the building, supply coal and light free and also supply a furnished teacher's residence.

We will have to pay the teacher's salary and supply some classroom equipment, such as desks, but the latter will not have to be purchased, as there are desks available from other schools in the agency.

In view of the number of children who are not receiving education, I feel that we should accept the Indian Commissioner's recommendation, and I enclose Memorandum to Council, as required by Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act.

Encl.

Director
